THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Hospital Land Partners, LLC, Appellant,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Coastal
          Resource Management, Respondent.
        
        Hall
          Development, Glenn Hall, Carl Hyszczak, Irene Hyszczak, June Darville,
          Charles Darville, Rose Suess, Carl Suess, George Pendleton, Carl Franklin,
          Mildred Borbet, Gladys Bride, John Bride, D. C. Abernethy, Leo Wever, Richard
          Smith, Donald Joy, Joan Joy, Renzo Falcinelli, Nancy Falcinelli, Joyce Utt,
          Boyd Parker, Anne Parker, Alfred Robertson, Ronald Longnecker, Bonnie
          Longnecker, William Besemer, Lee Besemer, Richard Geller, John Shaw, Norman
          Heindel, Stan Petroski, Patricia Hosford, and Leo Reddan, Respondents,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource
          Management, and Hospital Land Partners, LLC
        of which
          DHEC-OCRM is a Respondent
        and
        HLP is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-330
Heard May 6, 2008 â€“ Filed July 1, 2008
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled
September 23, 2008

REVERSED IN PART AND VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
        Leon Carroll Harmon, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        CarlisleÂ  Roberts, Jr., of Columbia, Cotton C. Harness, III, of
          Mt. Pleasant, EvanderÂ  Whitehead, of Charleston, James S. Chandler, Jr., of
          Pawleys Island, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â This
  action involves Hospital Land Partnersâ€™ (HLPâ€™s) application to obtain a
  stormwater management permit to allow for development of land set aside as a
  mitigation site for previous development.Â  We reverse in part, and vacate in
  part.Â Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
HLP owns an 8.55 acre parcel of property (the Property) near Conway, South Carolina.Â  The Property was once part of a larger tract owned by
  International Paper known as Southbridge.Â  In the early 1980â€™s, International
  Paper entered into an agreement with Glenn Hall for development of the
  property.Â  Pursuant to the agreement, Hall Development would develop the property
  and then purchase the lots from International Paper as the lots were finished.Â 
  Hall Development was responsible for obtaining state, local, and federal
  permits.Â  It obtained a permit from the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers and a
  coastal zone consistency certification from the State of South Carolina,
  through the South Carolina Coastal Council, which was the predecessor to the Department
  of Health and Environmental Controlâ€™s (DHECâ€™s) Office of Ocean and Coastal
  Resource Management (OCRM). Â Hall Development was allowed to fill three wetland
  areas, totaling 1.029 acres for Section VIII of Myrtle Trace Subdivision and
  dredge another area to make a lake.Â  As mitigation for this, Hall Development
  was to protect another wetland area consisting of 4.689 acres and establish a
  buffer around the wetlands.Â  The total mitigation site was 8.337 acres.Â  No
  conservation easement or restrictive covenants were placed on the Property,
  which remained titled to International Paper.Â  At the time, the policies of the
  Army Corps of Engineers and the Coastal Council did not include the requirement
  that a permittee record restrictive covenants and/or conservation easements to
  protect wetlands, wetland buffers, and land provided in mitigation.Â  
The
  members of HLP, Thomas Roe and Dr. Michael Hodge, became interested in the
  Property in late 1996 or early 1997.Â  Thomas Roe met with Allen Moore, an
  employee of International Paper in charge of the real estate portfolio,
  regarding the availability of the Property.Â  Moore told Roe that the Property
  was available but â€œmessed up.â€Â  Moore testified he told Roe that the Property
  had potential problems with a Corps of Engineers permit.Â  A partnership formed
  by Roe and Hodge, Hodge-Roe General Partnership, entered into an option
  agreement with International Paper to purchase the Property for $225,000.Â  The
  partnership paid only $10.00 for the option.Â  The attorney who conducted the
  title examination did not find any problems with the Property, other than a
  deed to the South Carolina Department of Transportation.Â  This matter was
  resolved.Â  The Partnership also commissioned a wetland redelineation to be
  conducted by the Brigman Company, which had also conducted the earlier wetlands
  delineation for Hall Development.Â  The delineation, which was approved by the
  Corps of Engineers and verified by OCRM, showed that less than 0.8 acres of
  wetlands remained on the site.Â  The reduction possibly resulted from a
  combination of factors, including changed Corps wetland delineation guidelines,
  the excavation of the adjacent wetland, and the creation of the drainage canal
  constructed earlier between the Property and Myrtle Trace.Â  
The Partnership purchased the Property on December 12, 1997 and
  subsequently deeded it to HLP.Â  The timber on the Property was harvested in
  April of 1998.Â  The residents of Myrtle Trace and Glenn Hall objected to any
  development of the Property.Â  When HLP applied to have the Property rezoned,
  the Horry County Planning Commission required HLP to obtain a letter from the
  Corps of Engineers concerning the status of the Property as a mitigation site.Â 
  The Corps responded that although the property was offered as mitigation for a
  permit, there were no easements or covenants in its records and HLP could
  proceed with any work in areas not designated as jurisdictional in the
  delineation.Â  OCRM refused to issue a similar letter because the Property had
  been offered by Hall Development as mitigation for wetlands filled by it.Â  
On July 7, 1999, HLP submitted an application to OCRM seeking a stormwater
  management and sediment control permit as required by the Stormwater Management
  and Sediment Reduction Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-14-30(A) (2008) (â€œUnless
  exempted, no person may engage in a land disturbing activity without first
  submitting a stormwater management and sediment control plan to the appropriate
  implementing agency and obtaining a permit to proceed.â€).Â  As part of this
  permitting process, OCRM was to ensure the proposed project, located in a
  coastal zone, was consistent with the policies of the Coastal Management
  Program managed by DHEC.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-39-80(B)(11) (2008)
  (authorizing DHEC to develop a plan to review all state and federal permit
  applications in the coastal zone, and to certify that these do not contravene the
  management plan).Â  In the application, HLP sought approval of a plan to disturb
  7.77 acres of land for construction of a residential care facility.Â  Although
  the application indicated that no wetlands would be disturbed, the area
  disturbed would include the mitigation site.Â  In a letter dated September 27,
  1999, OCRM informed HLP that the project was inconsistent with the Coastal Zone
  Management Program.Â  However, the letter set forth several conditions that, if
  accomplished, would bring the project into consistency.Â  These conditions were
  that HLP was to:

  a. Provide for a buffer
    around the wetlands on the HLP property and adjacent tract, which is adjacent
    to the southern property line of the HLP property;Â  
  b. Redirect storm water
    runoff at several locations into the wetlands;
  c. Replant vegetation to
    replace the vegetation that was cleared.Â  This was to re-establish the natural
    screen between the wetland and the upland area;Â  
  d. Purchase credits in an
    off-site mitigation bank, in order to mitigate for the difference in the amount
    of wetlands that were delineated in 1991 and the current amount.Â  The credits
    would be no more than $20,000;Â  
  e. Formally preserve all
    of the wetlands and buffers in the area with a standard deed restriction.[1]Â  

HLP
  appealed to the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ), contesting OCRMâ€™s
  requirements.Â  In addition, Hall Development and Glenn Hall (collectively Hall)
  and residents of Myrtle Trace appealed to the ALJ contesting the projectâ€™s
  consistency with the Coastal Zone Management Act, Coastal Zone Management
  Program Document, and the South Carolina Stormwater and Sedimentation Reduction
  Act.Â  The appeals were consolidated for one hearing.Â  On the second day of the
  hearing, HLP withdrew its claims of lack of authority by OCRM to require the conditions
  and agreed to all of the conditions set forth in OCRMâ€™s letter.Â  
The ALJ
  noted OCRM has significant discretion in any decision to grant or deny a
  coastal zone permit.Â  He concluded that the buffers and the purchase of credits
  in a mitigation bank to mitigate for the loss of wetlands that has occurred
  over time comply with the requirements of the Coastal Zone Management Program.Â 
  He rejected Hall and the Residentsâ€™ res judicata argument, finding the
  loss of wetlands on the property presented a change in circumstances not
  contemplated by OCRM in its original certification determination.Â  He found
  OCRMâ€™s proposed mitigation plan would protect the remaining wetlands more
  effectively than preservation of the status quo.Â  The ALJ ordered HLP to submit
  a stormwater management plan that incorporates the conditions listed in OCRMâ€™s
  September letter.Â  
Hall and the Residents appealed to the DHEC Board.Â  The DHEC Board
  initially rejected the ALJâ€™s findings of fact and made its own findings.Â  It
  reversed the decision of the ALJ and denied HLPâ€™s application for a storm water
  and sediment control permit.Â  HLP appealed to the circuit court, which vacated
  the decision of the DHEC Board for making its own findings of fact.[2]Â  After the remand, the DHEC Board
  found the Coastal Zone Management Program certification of Phase VIII of the
  Myrtle Trace development, which required the setting aside and protection of
  the buffer area as mitigation, constituted a final agency action.Â  It held that
  â€œ[o]nly in extraordinary cases can the terms and conditions of a final [Coastal
  Zone Management Program] certification be rescinded.Â  This is clearly not one
  of those cases.â€Â  It held that the effect of the ALJ order would be to allow
  development of the buffer area previously set aside as mitigation and this
  constituted an error of law.Â  It affirmed the ALJâ€™s findings of fact but
  reversed as to its conclusions of law.Â  Thus, it denied HLPâ€™s application for a
  permit.Â  
HLP appealed to the circuit court.Â  The court summarized the testimony
  presented at the hearing before the ALJ.Â  It held that the DHEC Boardâ€™s
  decision that once a piece of land is set aside as mitigation, it must stay set
  aside in the absence of extraordinary circumstances was squarely a ruling of
  law.Â  It concluded the Boardâ€™s ruling on this question of law had legal and
  factual support.Â  In affirming the Boardâ€™s order, the circuit court also
  addressed several additional sustaining grounds.Â  The court subsequently denied
  HLPâ€™s motion to alter or amend.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under the APA (Administrative Procedures Act), the Administrative
  Law Judge presides as the fact finder.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(B)
  (2005); [3] Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 520,
  560 S.E.2d 410, 417 (2002).Â  In reviewing the final decision of the ALJ, the
  DHEC Board sat as a quasi-judicial tribunal and was not entitled to make
  findings of fact.Â  Brown, 348 S.C. at 520, 560 S.E.2d at 417.Â  The DHEC
  Board can only reverse the ALJ based on an error of law or if his findings are
  not supported by substantial evidence.Â  See Dorman v. S.C. Depâ€™t of
    Health & Envtl. Control, 350 S.C. 159, 165, 565 S.E.2d 119, 122 (Ct. App.
  2002).Â  The circuit courtâ€™s review is the same as this courtâ€™s. Â It may reverse
  a decision of an administrative agency if the agencyâ€™s findings or conclusions
  are:

  (a) in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions;Â  
  (b) in excess of the statutory authority of the agency;Â  
  (c) made upon unlawful procedure;Â  
  (d) affected by other error of law;Â  
  (e) clearly erroneous in view of the
    reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record;Â  or 
  (f) arbitrary or capricious or
    characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of
    discretion.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).
â€œIn
  determining whether the ALJâ€™s decision was supported by substantial evidence,
  this court need only find, looking at the entire record on appeal, evidence
  from which reasonable minds could reach the same conclusion that the
  administrative agency reached.â€Â  DuRant v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
    Control, 361 S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d 704, 706 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThe mere
  possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not
  prevent a finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Id. at 420, 604 S.E.2d at 707. 
DISCUSSION
1.Â  Permit
  Application
HLP
  argues the DHEC Boardâ€™s order and the circuit courtâ€™s order are erroneous as a
  matter of law.Â  We agree.Â  
The
  DHEC Board ruled, â€œOnly in extraordinary cases can the terms and conditions of
  a final CZMP certification be rescinded.â€Â  It concluded this case did not meet
  that criteria.Â  DHEC is the agency in charge of enforcing and administering the
  provisions of the Coastal Zone Management Act and the rules and regulations
  promulgated under it.Â  S.C. Code Â§48-39-50 (2008).Â  In addition, DHEC is
  charged with the development of a comprehensive coastal management program and
  the enforcement and administration of this program.Â  S.C. Code Â§ 48-39-80
  (2008).Â  Its interpretation of these statutes and regulations is given great
  deference by the courts.Â  See Dunton v. S.C. Bd. of Examâ€™rs in
    Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987) (â€œ[T]he
  construction of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be
  accorded the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent
  compelling reasons.â€).Â  In the present case, however, neither the statutes nor
  the regulations promulgated thereunder set forth a requirement of an
  extraordinary case in order for a prior mitigation site to be modified.Â  The
  DHEC Board cannot create a new test by way of quasi-judicial order, but rather
  must promulgate such a test by regulation.Â  See Captainâ€™s Quarters
    Motor Inn v. S.C. Coastal Council, 306 S.C. 488, 491, 413 S.E.2d 13, 14
  (1991) (holding OCRMâ€™s predecessor, the South Carolina Coastal Council,
  overstepped its statutory authority in formulating and applying a damage
  assessment test for purposes of permit evaluations without formalizing it by
  regulation).Â  
Hall
  and the Residents assert that under the Coastal Zone Management Program
  Document, once a permit is issued, OCRM may not take any inconsistent action.Â 
  It asserts OCRM could not modify the original certification.Â  This provision
  actually provides, â€œIn those instances where more than one permit is required
  for a project, as long as no components of the project change, the Department
  will only place the first permit received on public notice.Â  The Department
  will take identical action on all sequential permits.â€Â  The provision simply
  allows that once OCRM determines a project is consistent with the Coastal Zone
  Management Program and issues the first permit, it will do the same with
  subsequent permits for the same project.Â  Thus, it could not grant one permit
  and then deny a subsequent permit for the same project.Â  
The
  instant case involves a permit application for an entirely different project
  than the development of Myrtle Trace in which the original mitigation site was
  set aside.Â  It does not involve the rescission of the original Coastal Zone
  Management Program certification; rather it simply allows a release of an area
  that was required to be set-aside as a mitigation site.Â  We find the above
  provision inapplicable to the present case.Â  
 We
  conclude the DHEC Board erred as a matter of law in creating a test not set
  forth in statute or regulation.Â  Therefore, we must affirm the ALJâ€™s findings
  and conclusion that HLPâ€™s project was consistent if there is substantial
  evidence in the record to support the decision.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).
The
  General Assembly mandated the specific state policy to be followed in the
  implementation of the Coastal Zone Management Act is: 

  [t]o promote economic and social improvement of the citizens of
    this State and to encourage development of coastal resources in order to
    achieve such improvement with due consideration for the environment and within
    the framework of a coastal planning program that is designed to protect the sensitive
    and fragile areas from inappropriate development and provide adequate
    environmental safeguards with respect to the construction of facilities in the
    critical areas of the coastal zone . . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  48-39-30(B)(1) (2008).Â  
In
  furtherance of this policy, the General Assembly set forth considerations in
  the approval or denial of a permit, which include:

  (7) The extent of the economic benefits as compared with the
    benefits from preservation of an area in its unaltered state.
    (8) The extent of any adverse environmental impact which cannot be
    avoided by reasonable safeguards. 
    (10) The extent to which the proposed use could affect the value
    and enjoyment of adjacent owners. 
  
S. C. Code Ann. Â§
  48-39-150 (2008).Â  
In
  addition, OCRMâ€™s Coastal Zone Management Program Document provides additional
  guidelines for evaluating projects, including â€œthe extent to which the project
  includes consideration for the maintenance or improvement of the economic
  stability of the coastal communities,â€ and the â€œpossible long-range, cumulative
  effects of the project, when reviewed in the context of other possible
  development and the general character of the area.â€Â  
The ALJ
  considered these factors in concluding that OCRM adequately evaluated the
  project and correctly found that the project, as revised, was consistent with
  the Coastal Zone Management Program.Â  Robert Mikell, manager of federal
  certification for OCRM, testified that if HLP made the changes set forth in the
  September of 1999 letter, the project would be in compliance with the Coastal
  Zone Management Program.Â  The amount of wetlands on the Property significantly
  decreased since the Property was originally set aside as a mitigation site.Â 
  This decrease, due in part to the lake and canal constructed in Myrtle Trace,
  happened before HLP purchased the property.Â  Mikell stated that the HLP project
  does not directly impact the remaining wetlands on the Property as they will
  not be filled, excavated, or dredged.Â  
The ALJ
  also considered the modifications OCRM required in its September of 1999
  letter.Â  The first requirement set forth in the letter is buffering.Â  Although
  OCRMâ€™s Coastal Zone Management Program document suggests that commercial
  buffers should be at least an average of 50 feet, OCRM allowed a buffer of an
  average of 32 feet for this project.Â  Mikell testified that a 32-foot buffer
  can be acceptable depending on the area that is being buffered, the size of the
  wetland, the type of development, the site plan, and the fact that the project
  does not impact wetlands.Â  The ALJ concluded the buffer in place was adequate
  of function as intended.Â  There is substantial evidence to support this
  finding.Â Â  
 The
  next requirement was altering the stormwater plan to show runoff being routed
  to the wetland system from several points.Â  Mikell stated that by redirecting
  the water, the wetlands were not likely to further retreat and would either
  stay the same or perhaps increase.Â  
The third requirement was replanting the wetland/buffer area to
  improve the screening features adjacent to the wetlands.Â  This screening will
  benefit the adjacent property owners and will grow over the years.Â  
The fourth requirement was HLP would purchase credits at an
  approved mitigation bank a sum to compensate for lost wetlands and buffer
  area.Â  Mikell calculated the payment would be approximately $20,000.Â  OCRMâ€™s
  mitigation guidelines allow for off-site mitigation â€œif the mitigation will
  provide significant ecological benefit to the State of South Carolina.â€Â  Mikell
  testified that the mitigation banks to which HLP is required to purchase
  credits are all located in areas that the state have deemed worthy of being
  restored.Â  Thus, in his opinion, all of the banks have been identified as being
  of ecological benefit to the State.Â  
The
  final requirement was that the wetlands and buffers must be preserved using
  standard deed restrictions.Â  This requirement eliminates any uncertainty in the
  protection of the remaining wetlands.Â  
The ALJ held, â€œOCRMâ€™s proposed mitigation plan would protect the
  remaining wetlands more effectively than preservation of the status quo. . . .Â 
  Given that the topography of the wetlands [has] changed since 1989, OCRMâ€™s
  proposed mitigation plan appropriately alters the status of the property upon
  reassessment of its physical characteristics.â€Â  We hold there is substantial
  evidence in the record to support this finding
The ALJ
  also considered the Residentsâ€™ argument concerning diminution of property
  values.Â  A property owner is competent to testify as to the value of his
  property.Â  Hawkins v. Greenwood Dev. Corp., 328 S.C. 585, 594-95, 493
  S.E.2d 875, 880 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  However, Myrtle Trace property owner Renzo
  Falcinelli only testified he believed his property value had gone down.Â 
  Neither he nor any other Resident provided actual evidence of the amount of a
  decrease in value.Â  They failed to offer evidence of sales of similar property
  showing the presence of a similar project in the coastal zone had materially
  and negatively impacted the value of adjacent ownerâ€™s property.Â  Falcinelli
  also testified about his loss of enjoyment of the use of his property due to
  the harvesting of the trees.Â  OCRMâ€™s requirement for replanting the buffer area
  should help restore the screening and alleviate some of his and the other
  ownerâ€™s concerns.Â  
The ALJ
  addressed Hall and Residentsâ€™ argument that the project is not consistent with
  the Coastal Zone Management Program because zoning approval has not been
  obtained.Â  As the ALJ noted, zoning compliance is just one of many factors set
  forth in the Coastal Zone Management Program Document for OCRM to consider.Â 
  Here, the local zoning authorities deferred action on HLPâ€™s rezoning request
  until HLP could receive clearance from OCRM to deviate from the previous buffer
  requirements.Â  We agree with the ALJ that the absence of zoning approval in
  this case did not render the project inconsistent with the Coastal Zone
  Management Program.Â  
The
  Coastal Zone Management Act and OCRMâ€™s Coastal Zone Management Program Document
  set forth the considerations to be utilized in achieving the stateâ€™s policy of
  balancing economic development and preservation of the environment.Â  Achieving
  this balance requires flexibility and contemplation of the actual circumstances
  involved in each projectâ€™s permit application.Â  OCRM has allowed modification
  in other plans according to Mikell.Â  In this case, the wetlands on the area
  diminished significantly.Â  The current plan will allow for preservation of the
  remaining wetlands and in addition will provide for payment into the mitigation
  bank to allow for restoration and preservation of an area in need.Â 
  Accordingly, we find substantial evidence supports the ALJâ€™s decision a
  stormwater management plan that incorporates the requirements in OCRMâ€™s
  September, 1999 letter is consistent with the Coastal Zone Management Program.Â  
2.Â  Additional
  sustaining grounds
The
  circuit court ruled as an additional sustaining ground that the ALJ erred by
  refusing to consider fundamental principles of property law.Â  The court held
  that Roe had constructive and actual knowledge of the mitigation requirements
  prior to HLPâ€™s acquisition of the property.Â  However, the ALJ never held HLP
  was not bound by the prior mitigation restrictions.Â  In fact, OCRMâ€™s position
  was that the mitigation restrictions were in place and binding on HLP.Â  The
  requirement that HLP purchase credits in an off-site mitigation bank was to
  mitigate for the difference in the amount of wetlands in the original
  delineation and the current amount.Â  Although HLP initially contested OCRMâ€™s
  additional conditions, it later agreed to them and its notice of the mitigation
  site was not an issue.Â  
The
  circuit court also held the ALJ ignored the equitable, economic, and property
  interests of Hall and the Myrtle Trace residents.Â  As stated above, the extent
  to which the project affects the value and enjoyment of adjacent owners was a
  factor considered by the ALJ in determining whether the project was consistent
  with the Coastal Zone Management Program.Â  As we found above, the ALJâ€™s finding
  of consistency is supported by substantial evidence.Â  
To the
  extent the circuit court relied on other aspects of property law, we vacate
  these rulings.Â  The sole issue in this case is whether the HLP project is
  consistent with the Coastal Zone Management Program in order that HLP may
  receive a Stormwater permit to proceed with the project.Â  As the ALJ stated,
  any issues relating to real property law should be resolved in another forum.Â  
As
  another additional sustaining ground, the circuit court held the ALJ erred by
  turning a mere settlement proposal into a final staff decision.Â  OCRMâ€™s
  September of 1999 letter set forth the requirements that must be included in a
  revision of HLPâ€™s plans for the project.Â  Although the letter termed it a
  â€œmitigation settlement plan,â€ HLP was entitled to seek an administrative
  hearing on this matter.Â  See 26 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 72-313(A)(5) (Supp.
  2007) (stating an administrative hearing is available to determine the
  propriety of the requirements imposed by the implementing agency for approval
  of the stormwater management and sediment reduction plan).Â  At this
  administrative hearing, Hall and the Residents were allowed to present their
  opposition to the project and were given an opportunity to be heard on the
  consistency of OCRMâ€™s proposed mitigation plan with the Coastal Zone Management
  Program in a contested case proceeding.Â  We find the circuit courtâ€™s ruling was
  in error.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We REVERSE the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the DHEC
  Boardâ€™s denial of HLPâ€™s permit application and reinstate the order of the ALJ
  allowing HLP to resubmit a stormwater plan including OCRMâ€™s additional
  conditions.Â  In addition, we VACATE the circuit courtâ€™s rulings on
  property law issues.Â  
REVERSED
  IN PART; VACATED IN PART.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] OCRM also required HLP to raise the outfall
  structure that is located adjacent to the canal in the Myrtle Trace
  Subdivision.Â  However, further review indicated this may cause flooding and
OCRM withdrew this condition.Â  
[2] During the pendency of the initial appeal to circuit
  court, the supreme court had issued an opinion restricting the Boardâ€™s
  authority to make findings of fact.Â  See Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
Control, 348 S.C. 507, 560 S.E.2d 410 (2002).Â  
[3]This case progressed under the procedures in place
  prior to 2006 revision of the Administrative
  Procedures Act, which omitted the appeals to the DHEC Board and the circuit
  court.Â  See Act. No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 3093, 3098-3103.Â  All citations
are to the former versions of the statutes found in the 2005 bound volume.Â

  this defamation action, Diana Holt appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s
  determination she is a limited public figure while James M. Holloway, Jr. and
  The Index Journal Company appeal from the circuit courtâ€™s denial of their
  motion for summary judgment.Â  We dismiss the appeal pursuant to Rule 220(b),
  SCACR, and the following authorities: Holtâ€™s Appeal: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(2) (1976)
  (stating interlocutory orders affecting a
  substantial right may be immediately appealed if they in effect determine the action and prevent a judgment from which an appeal
  might be taken); Mid-State Distributors, Inc. v. Century Importers,
    Inc., 310 S.C. 330, 335, 426 S.E.2d 777, 780 (1993) (â€œSouth Carolina case law has established what constitutes
  an interlocutory appeal. If there is some further act which must be done by the
  court prior to a determination of the rights of the parties, then the order is
  interlocutory. If a judgment determines the applicable law while leaving open
  questions of fact, it is not a final judgment.â€) (citations omitted); Holloway and The Index Journalâ€™s Cross
  Appeal: Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476,
  477-78, 443 S.E.2d 379, 380 (1994) (â€œ[t]he denial of summary judgment does not finally
  determine anything about the merits of the case and does not have the effect of striking any defense since
  that defense may be raised again later in the proceedings.Â  Therefore,
  an order denying a motion for summary judgment is not appealable.â€); Wright
    v. Craft, 372 S.C. 1, 34-35, 640 S.E.2d 486, 504 (Ct. App. 2006) (explaining
  the court would adhere to recent precedent and refrain from addressing a denial
  of summary judgment).
APPEAL
  DISMISSED.
WILLIAMS,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Case No.:
      2006-CP-07-01418 BillyBobâ€™s Marina, Inc., d/b/a Outdoor Resort and Yacht
      Club, Appellant,
				v.
				Dwight
      Blakeslee, Respondent.
				Case No.:Â 
      2006-CP-07-01477 BillyBobâ€™s Marina, Inc., d/b/a Hilton Head Harbor RV Resorts and Marina, Appellant,
				v.
				George Martin, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Special Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-332
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed July 1,
  2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia and James O. Hale, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
				John R. C. Bowen, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  BillyBobâ€™s Marina, Inc., d/b/a Outdoor Resort and Yacht Club (BillyBob), filed
  these actions against Dwight Blakeslee and George Martin. Â The trial court
  granted summary judgment to Blakeslee and Martin.Â  BillyBob appeals.Â  We
  affirm.[1]
FACTS[2]
Outdoor
  Resorts RV Resort and Yacht Club (the Development) is a recreational vehicle
  (RV) resort and marina located on Jenkins Island in Beaufort County.Â  From the Developmentâ€™s inception in 1981, it has consisted of several separate areas
  including a marina, the resort including 200 lots with parking pads for RVs
  (lots), and a real estate and rental management business.Â  The Development, a
  South Carolina General Partnership, developed the resort and owned the marina
  and rental management business.Â  In June 1981, the â€œDeclaration of Covenants
  and Restrictions for Outdoor Resorts, R.V. Resort and Yacht Club and Provisions
  for the R.V. Resort and Yacht Club Ownersâ€™ Association, Inc.â€ (the Covenants)
  were recorded.Â Â  
The
  Covenants provide the Developer has the exclusive right to rent lots belonging
  to the individual owners within the resort when not occupied by the owner(s)
  and his or her guest(s) at the scheduled rate promulgated by the Developer.Â 
  The Covenants further provide the Developer shall retain fifty percent â€œof
  rental collected on any Lotâ€ and remit the remaining fifty percent to the lot
  owner.Â Â Â Â  
On
  August 31, 1999, BillyBob purchased the marina and rental management
  businesses, real estate in the Development, and the Developerâ€™s right to rent
  lots.Â  Based on BillyBobâ€™s changes in restrictions and fee collections, the
  Association and several lot owners filed an action alleging, inter alia,
  BillyBob violated the Covenants.Â  BillyBob counterclaimed asserting numerous
  violations of the Covenants including Blakesleeâ€™s alleged violation of a
  covenant restricting permanent residences in the resort.Â  The referee found, inter
    alia, Blakeslee was not in violation
  of the Covenants.Â  BillyBob appealed to this court, and in RV Resort v. BillyBobâ€™s Marina, Inc., this court affirmed the refereeâ€™s finding.
During
  the pendency of that action, BillyBob filed these actions, again alleging Blakeslee was in violation of the covenant
  restricting permanent residences.Â  BillyBob likewise alleged Martinâ€™s use
  violated the Covenants.Â  In separate orders, the trial court found neither Blakeslee
  nor Martin violated the Covenants.Â  The trial court also awarded Blakeslee and
  Martin attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  BillyBob appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The character of an action as legal or equitable depends on the
  relief sought.Â  Cedar Cove
    Homeowners Assâ€™n v. DiPietro, 368 S.C. 254, 258, 628 S.E.2d 284, 286 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  An action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is an equitable action. Â South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617,
  622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001).Â  In an action in equity, we may find facts in accordance with our
  own view of the evidence.Â  Id. Â â€œAs a practical matter, however, we . . . defer to the good judgment of the trial court who heard and observed the witnesses.â€Â  Costa &
    Sons Constr. Co. v. Long, 306 S.C. 465, 468, 412 S.E.2d 450, 452 (Ct. App.
  1991).
LAW/ANALYSIS

BillyBob
  argues the trial court erred in finding the Covenants do not prohibit lot
  owners from permanently residing on their lots.Â  We disagree.Â  

	Article
  VIII, section 8.1, of the Covenants states: 
	
		It is the specific intent of this Declaration to
  create and maintain a lu[x]ury resort for recreation vehicles and to prohibit
  permanent or semi-permanent structures as well as any structure or vehicle
  which is used as, or designed for use as, permanent living quarters on any Lot.Â  In that regard, all Lots . . . shall be reserved and restricted for recreation
  campsites and camping vehicles, including . . . modern travel trailers . . .
  and other similar types of camping trailers and equipment that are mobile. . .
  .Â  Lot Owners . . . are prohibited from erecting or placing on any Lot any permanent or semi-permanent structure or any vehicle which is designed as permanent
  living quarters, which prohibited structures include, without limitation, the
  following:Â  (a) screen rooms, carport, metal awnings . . . ; (b) travel
  trailers longer than thirty-five (35) feet . . . ; (c) mobile homes; (d) any
  structure which cannot be transported within the pulling vehicle . . . ; (e)
  any structure placed on the Lot on blocks . . . ; (f) any structure not
  intended to be temporary, that is, any structure intended not to be readily
  movable; and (g) any structure designed, intended or used as permanent living
  quarters.Â  Provided, this paragraph is not intended to prohibit or limit the
  utilization of otherwise permissible recreation vehicles as described above . .
  . .Â  It is the declared intent of the Developer to exclude mobile homes from
  being placed on any Lot, and to create and maintain an area designated for
  maximum beauty and benefit of campers. 
	

Blakeslee
  and Marvin own travel trailers that are not restricted by the Covenants.Â 
  BillyBob presented evidence that Blakeslee lives exclusively in his travel
  trailer, resided for more than twelve consecutive months on his lot in the
  resort, and claimed the homestead exemption for his lot.Â  See S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 12-37-250 (Supp. 2007) (providing real estate taxation relief for
  dwelling place).Â  BillyBob likewise alleged Martin used his lot as permanent
  living quarters.[3]Â 
  BillyBob relies on the language prohibiting â€œpermanent living quartersâ€ to
  argue the Covenants restrict the amount of time a Lot owner may spend on his or
  her lot.Â Â  
Restrictive
  covenants are contractual in nature and rules of contract interpretation
  apply.Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 166, 631 S.E.2d 539, 542 (2006).Â 
  However, restrictions on the use of property are strictly construed with all
  doubts resolved in favor of the free use of property.Â  Id.Â  
Reading
  Article VIII, section 8.1, of the Covenants as a whole, we agree with the trial
  court that the covenant is intended to exclude mobile homes and permanent
  structures so as to prevent the resort from becoming a mobile home park.Â  The
  Covenants do not place any limit on the amount of time owners may use or occupy
  their lots. We do not read the language prohibiting â€œpermanent living quartersâ€
  as restricting an ownerâ€™s use of their lot to a certain period of time when
  they are using an otherwise acceptable vehicle on the lot.Â  We find support for
  this interpretation in the Covenantâ€™s provision stating: â€œthis paragraph is not
  intended to prohibit or limit the utilization of otherwise permissible
  recreation vehicles . . . . It is the declared intent of the Developer to
  exclude mobile homes from being placed on any Lot, and to create and maintain
  an area designated for maximum beauty and benefit of campers.â€Â  Accordingly, we
  find the trial court did not err in finding the Covenants do not prohibit lot
  owners from permanently residing on their lots.
BillyBob also
  argues the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs should be reversed if we reverse
  the trial courtâ€™s orders finding Blakeslee and Martin did not violate the
  Covenants.Â  Because we affirm said orders, we likewise affirm the orders
  granting attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. 
For the foregoing
  reasons, the orders on appeal are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur. 


[1]  We
decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  Some of the facts in this case are as reported
  in RV Resort v. BillyBobâ€™s Marina, Inc., Op. No. 2007-UP-556 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Dec. 14, 2007).
[3]  Martin presented evidence he does not
  permanently reside on the lot but travels throughout the year in the trailer
and also travels to a home in England.Â

PER
  CURIAM: Â Jerry Hughes appeals his

  substance (morphine).Â  Hughes asserts the detention and subsequent request for
  consent to search exceeded the scope of the original stop, and the scope of any

    Rowe, 192 S.C. 12, 5 S.E.2d 187 (1939) (stating the questions presented for
  appellate review must first have been fairly and properly raised in the lower
  court and passed upon by that court); Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant,
  338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (finding a losing party must
  first try to convince the lower court it has ruled wrongly and then, if that
  effort fails, convince the appellate court that the lower court erred); State
    v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 656, 576 S.E.2d 168, 179 (2003) (determining whether
  consent to search is voluntary is a question of fact to be resolved from the
  totality of the circumstances); State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 528
  S.E.2d 661, 665-66 (2000) (applying a â€œclearly erroneousâ€ standard of
  review in determining whether trial judge properly held defendant consented to
  search); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 585-86, 575 S.E.2d 852, 856
  (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œThe scope of the consent is measured by a test of â€˜objective
  reasonableness-what would the typical reasonable person have understood by the
  exchange between the officer and the suspect?â€™â€); c.f. State v.
    Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001) (finding a suspectâ€™s overt
  act of merely opening the pocket book for inspection after consent was
  requested, limited the scope of the general grant of consent previously given).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and SHORT, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				D.R. Horton,
      Inc., Respondent,
				v.
				Campus Housing
      Company, LLC, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis Coltrane, Special Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â Â  2008-UP-335 Â 
Heard May 8, 2008 â€“ Filed July 1, 2008
AFFIRMED 


	
		
			
				Barry Johnson and Jason Ward, both of Okatie, for Appellant.
				James Herring and G. Hamlin Oâ€™Kelley, Â both of Bluffton, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Campus
  Housing Company, LLC (Campus Housing) appeals the trial courtâ€™s order denying
  its claims for reformation and specific performance of a land sale contract entered
  into with D.R. Horton, Inc. (Horton).Â  We affirm. Â Â 
FACTS
On January 29, 2003, Horton and Campus Housing entered into a contract
  for the purchase of real estate in Beaufort County.Â  Pursuant to the contract,
  Campus Housing was obligated to make deposits into escrow in four separate
  amounts at specific times.[1]Â 
  The contract also provided the â€œSeller will have reasonable ARB [Architectural
  Review Board] approval over the product that will be built by the Purchaser,
  with said ARB guidelines being provided to the Purchaser by the Seller during
  the Due Diligence Period.â€
On November 19, 2003, the parties amended the original contract
  with an â€œAddendum to Purchase Agreementâ€ (Addendum).Â  In the Addendum, Campus Housing
  had until April 25, 2004 to complete its due diligence study on the property to
  determine the suitability of the property for its intended use.Â  Campus Housing
  could then choose to either terminate the agreement or make the final deposit
  into escrow.
On April 2, 2004, Horton and Campus Housing entered into a new
  contract for the purchase and sale of additional property in Beaufort County.Â  The new contract also gave Campus Housing until April 25, 2004 to complete
  its due diligence study to determine if it wanted to make the final deposit
  into escrow.
By letter dated April 21, 2004, Campus Housing informed Horton that
  pursuant to the contract, it believed the deadline for delivering its ARB
  guidelines (guidelines) to Campus Housing was April 7, 2003, more than a year
  prior to the date of the letter.Â  Therefore, Campus Housing argued the due
  diligence period should be extended for a period equal to the time between the
  due date and the date Horton would be providing the guidelines to Campus
  Housing.Â  In a second letter, Campus Housing further claimed it was not
  required to close until Horton provided the guidelines, even though the original
  contract set the closing for fifteen days after the end of the due diligence
  period.Â  Horton rejected Campus Housingâ€™s argument, claiming the delivery of
  the guidelines was not a condition precedent to Campus Housingâ€™s obligation to
  make the escrow deposits.
As of April 26, 2004, Campus Housing had not made the final
  deposits into escrow or terminated either contract.Â  On April 26, Campus
  Housing sent notices to Horton alleging Horton was in default under the terms
  of both contracts.Â  Specifically, Campus Housing claimed Horton failed to timely
  provide the guidelines because Horton was obligated under the contracts to
  provide the guidelines to Campus Housing during the time period Campus Housing
  was required to complete its due diligence studies.Â  The following day, Horton
  sent a notice of default to Campus Housing for failure to make the escrow payments.Â 
  According to the original contract, each party was entitled to written notice
  of default and would have fifteen days from the receipt of the notice to cure
  the alleged defect.
On April 30, 2004, Horton wrote to Campus Housing providing the guidelines
  Horton intended to impose on the land: 

	[T]he only [guidelines] which Horton will impose on [the land] . .
  . would be Hortonâ€™s prior written approval of the design and exterior color of
  any improvements [to the land] within 100â€™ of the propertiesâ€™ common boundary
  line with property owned by [Horton] and within 150â€™ of the intersection of any
  right of way at the point where such right of way crosses from property owned
  by [Horton] into properties owned by Campus Housing.

The letter
  further stated â€œif [Campus Housing] purchases all properties . . . currently
  under contract to purchase from [Horton] there will be no [guidelines] imposed
  by [Horton].â€
On May 3, 2004, Campus Housing wrote to Horton asking for
  clarification as to what guidelines Horton planned to employ.Â  In response,
  Horton wrote Campus Housing the next day addressing Campus Housingâ€™s
  questions.Â  However, Campus Housing contended Hortonâ€™s letters did not
  sufficiently provide the â€œarchitectural guidelinesâ€ required by the contract.Â  Neither
  the original contract nor the Addendum defines what the parties intended by the
  term â€œguidelines.â€
Subsequently, Horton wrote to Campus Housing informing them Horton
  was willing to enter into negotiations to revive the January 29 contract because
  Horton considered the contracts to be terminated due to Campus Housingâ€™s
  failure to timely make their payments.Â  The same day, Campus Housing wrote to
  Horton contending Horton had not provided the guidelines as required and rejecting
  Hortonâ€™s assertion the contracts had been terminated.
On May 26, 2004, Horton filed a declaratory judgment action
  against Campus Housing for breach of contract.Â  On June 2, Campus Housing filed
  its answer and counterclaims for reformation and special performance.Â  After a
  trial without a jury, the trial court issued its order denying both partiesâ€™
  claims.Â  Both parties filed Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motions to alter or amend, which
  the court denied on February 8, 2007.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA
  suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined
  by the nature of the underlying issue.â€ Â Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of Cal., 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).[2]Â 
  Reformation of a contract and an action for specific performance are actions in
  equity.Â  Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fidelity & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81,
  557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001); Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C.
  98, 531 S.E.2d 287 (2000); see Godfrey v. E.P. Burton Lumber Co.,
  88 S.C. 132, 133, 70 S.E. 396, 397 (1910).Â  In an action in equity, tried by
  the judge alone, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in
  accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Townes
    Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775
  (1976).Â  However, we are not required to disregard the factual findings of the trial
  court, who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to judge
  their credibility.Â  Smith v. Barr, 375 S.C. 157, 160, 650 S.E.2d 486,
  488 (Ct. App. 2007). 
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.  Architectural Guidelines
Campus
  Housing argues the trial court erred in finding Horton fulfilled its obligation
  to provide guidelines to Campus Housing because the materials provided were not
  as contemplated by the parties.Â  We disagree.
Campus Housing contends Hortonâ€™s letters did not provide the
  guidelines required by the contract; however, the contracts did not define what
  the parties intended by the use of the word â€œguidelines.â€Â  The January 29 contract
  provided the â€œSeller will have reasonable ARB [Architectural Review Board]
  approval over the product that will be built by the Purchaser, with said ARB
  guidelines being provided to the Purchaser by the Seller during the Due
  Diligence Period.â€Â  In a letter to Campus Housing, Horton stated the only guidelines
  Horton would impose on the land would be Hortonâ€™s prior written approval of the
  design and exterior color of any improvements to the land within 100 feet of
  the propertiesâ€™ common boundary line with property owned by Horton and within
  150 feet of the intersection of any right of way at the point where such right
  of way crosses from property owned by Horton into properties owned by Campus
  Housing.Â  Horton also added the review rights would not be unreasonable and
  Campus Housing was â€œfree to develop its property as it likes.â€Â  The letter
  further stated that if Campus Housing purchased all the properties it was under
  contract to purchase from Horton, Horton would not impose any guidelines.
Thus, sufficient evidence in
  the record supports the trial courtâ€™s finding the contracts did not state what
  the parties meant by â€œguidelinesâ€ and Hortonâ€™s letters were sufficient to fulfill its obligation under
  the contract.
II.Â 
  Specific Performance
Campus
  Housing also claims the trial court erred in holding Campus Housing was
  required to prove it was financially ready to close the deal to demand specific
  performance.Â  We disagree.
â€œSpecific
  performance should be granted only if there is no adequate remedy at law and
  specific enforcement of the contract is equitable between the parties.â€Â  Ingram
    v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98, 106, 531 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2000).Â  In Ingram,
  the Supreme Court of South Carolina held to compel specific performance, a
  court of equity must find: 

	(1) [T]here
  is clear evidence of a valid agreement; (2) the agreement had been partly
  carried into execution on one side with the approbation of the other; and (3)
  the party who comes to compel performance has performed his or her part, or has
  been and remains able and willing to perform his or her part of the contract.

Id. 
Here,
  Campus Housing meets the first two elements of specific performance as
  evidenced by record: (1) Horton and Campus Housing had a valid agreement and (2)
  Campus Housing met its obligations prior to April 26, 2004.Â  However, Campus
  Housing also had to prove the ability to perform part of the contract on June
  2, 2004, the date it brought an action for specific performance.Â  While evidence
  in the record suggests Campus Housing made efforts to obtain the money to close
  on the contracts, the evidence presented fails to show Campus Housing had the
  funds to do so on June 2, 2004.Â  Also, the managing director of Campus Housing,
  Craig Germain, testified during his deposition that Campus Housing did not have
  the money to close the deal as of May 10, or June 10, 2004.Â  Germain also
  stated Campus Housing did not have the money in its account to pay the final
  escrow deposits when they were due on April 26, 2004.
Therefore,
  Campus Housing failed to meet the third required element of its claim for
  specific performance and the trial court did not err by determining Campus
  Housing did not have the funds to purchase the property at the time it filed
  its action for specific performance.Â  Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Because the contracts did not define what the parties intended by
  the use of the word â€œguidelines,â€ the trial court was correct in finding Hortonâ€™s letter fulfilled its obligation to
  Campus Housing.Â  Also, the trial court correctly held Campus Housing
  failed to meet a required element of its claim for specific performance because
  the evidence presented showed Campus Housing did not have the necessary funds
  to purchase the land when the action was filed.Â  Therefore, the order of the
  trial court is Â 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  By
  July 2003, Campus Housing made the first three required deposits into escrow.
[2]Â  The claims presented to the trial court were both
  legal and equitable.Â  Horton filed a complaint alleging breach of contract,
  which is an action at law.Â  Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Langford, 330 S.C.
  578, 581, 500 S.E.2d 496, 497 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Campus Housing answered
  alleging claims for reformation and specific performance, which are actions in
  equity.Â  Because Horton did not appeal the trial courtâ€™s order, we need only
  look at the scope of review for an action in equity.Â  See Kiriakides
    v. Atlas Food Sys. & Servs, Inc., 338 S.C. 572, 580, 527 S.E.2d 371,
  375 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Corley v. Ott, 326 S.C. 89, 92 n.1, 485
  S.E.2d 97, 99 n.1 (1997) (â€œWhen legal and equitable actions are maintained in
  one suit, each retains its own identity as legal or equitable for purposes of
  the applicable standard of review on appeal.â€)).

THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In
  The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Premier Holdings, LLC, a Utah Limited Liability Company, and
          Premier Resorts, International, Inc., a Delaware corporation, Respondents,
        v.
        Barefoot Resort Golf Club II, LLC, a South Carolina Limited
          Liability Company, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal
From Horry County
Â J.
Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished
Opinion No. 2008-UP-336
Submitted
June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed July 2, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        C.
          Mitchell Brown, of Columbia, and Ian S. Ford, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        J.
          Jackson Thomas, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  PER
  CURIAM:Â 
  Barefoot Resort Golf Club, II, LLC (â€œBarefootâ€) appeals inter alia the
  masterâ€™s finding that it breached a valid contract with Premier Holdings, LLC
  and Premier Resorts, International, Inc. (collectively â€œPremierâ€).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Barefoot is owner and
  operator of three golf courses at the Barefoot Resort in North Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.[2]Â 
  Premier manages large, condominium-resort properties throughout the United States and Mexico and manages properties at the Barefoot Resort.Â  Legends Barefoot had borrowed
  three million dollars from Premier in July of 2002 to pay for purchasing its
  interest in the courses.Â  The parties agreed to an extension of the loan in July
  of 2003.Â  They executed numerous documents in conjunction with the extension of
  the loan.Â  One of these documents was a Shared Services Agreement (â€œSSAâ€).Â  The
  SSA provided several benefits to Premier to help â€œensure the availability of
  golf tee times for clients of Premier.â€Â  These benefits included giving Premier
  control of the tee time sheets for Barefoot, blocking certain tee times for
  Premier customers and paying Premier a four percent commission on all golf tee
  times booked by Premier.Â  
In January of 2005,
  Barefoot took control of the tee time sheets away from Premier.Â  Premier filed
  suit for breach of contract alleging Barefoot had violated the provisions of
  the SSA.Â  Barefoot answered alleging the SSA was not an enforceable contract
  because it lacked material terms, specifically, a contract duration. Â The
  master-in-equity found the contract was enforceable and the duration of the
  contract was â€œfor as long asâ€ Premier continued doing business at Barefoot.Â  The
  master further held Barefoot had breached the SSA and awarded Premier damages
  in the amount of $161,369.Â  Barefoot appeals.Â Â  
STANDARD OF
REVIEW
â€œAn action to construe a contract is an action at law. Â Likewise, â€˜[a]n
  action for breach of contract seeking money damages is an
  action at law.â€™â€ Silver v. Aabstract Pools & Spas, Inc., 376 S.C.
  585, 590, 658 S.E.2d 539, 541-42. (Ct. App. 2008) (quoting R & G
    Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 430, 540
  S.E.2d 113, 117 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  On appeal from a final judgment of the
  master in a law case tried without a jury, â€œwe may not consider the case based
  on our own view of the preponderance of the evidence, but must view the record
  so as to support the masterâ€™s findings of fact whenever reasonably possible.â€ South Carolina Fed. Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby Dev. Co., 303 S.C. 74, 78,
  399 S.E.2d 8, 11 (Ct. App. 1990) (citing Sheek v. Crimestoppers Alarm Sys.,
  297 S.C. 375, 377 S.E.2d 132 (Ct. App. 1989)). Â â€œIn other words, we must
  consider the evidence in the light most favorable to the respondent,
  eliminating from consideration evidence to the contrary.â€ Â Id. at 79,
  399 S.E.2d at 11.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Enforceability
  of Contract/Duration of Contract[3]
Barefoot
  argues the master erred in finding the SSA to be a valid and enforceable
  contract where material terms were omitted.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œIt
  is well settled in South Carolina that in order for there to be a binding
  contract between parties, there must be a mutual manifestation of assent to the
  terms.â€ Â Edens v. Laurel Hill, Inc., 271 S.C. 360, 364, 247
  S.E.2d 434, 436 (1978). Â â€œSome terms are considered indispensable to a binding
  contract. Â Among these are price, time and place.â€Â  Id.Â  However,
  as noted by the master in his order, the requirement of a specific duration for
  the enforcement of a contract is not limited solely to a calendar date, but may
  be provided upon the occurrence of a specific event.Â  Prestwick Golf Club,
    Inc. v. Prestwick Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 331 S.C. 385, 392, 503 S.E.2d 184, 187-88
  (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
â€œAlthough
  the interpretation of a contract is generally a matter of law, the intent of
  the parties becomes a question of fact . . . when the contract is ambiguous.â€Â  Id. at 390, 503 S.E.2d at 187.Â  â€œAn ambiguous contract is a contract capable of
  being understood in more than one way or a contract unclear in meaning because
  it expresses its purpose in an indefinite manner.â€Â  HK New Plan Exchange
    Prop. Owner I, LLC v. Coker, 375 S.C. 18, 24, 649 S.E.2d 181, 184 (Ct. App.
  2007). Â When a contract is ambiguous, the courtâ€™s primary objective must be to
  discern the intent of the parties.Â  Ecclesiastes
    Prod. Ministries v. Outparcel Assocs., 374
  S.C. 483, 497, 649 S.E.2d 494, 501 (Ct.
  App. 2007).Â  In ascertaining intent, the court will examine the
  totality of the contract and the language used by the parties.Â  The court will
  also strive to discover the situation of the parties, along with their purposes
  at the time they entered the contract.Â  Id. at 498, 649 S.E.2d at 502. Â â€œIn
  arriving at the intention of the parties . . . , the subject matter, the
  surrounding circumstances, the situation of the parties, and the object in view
  and intended to be accomplished by the parties at the time, are to be regarded.â€Â  Id. at 499, 649 S.E.2d at 502 (quoting Brady v. Brady, 222 S.C. 242, 246-47, 72Â  S.E.2d 193, 195
  (1952)).
We agree with the masterâ€™s finding the duration of the SSA is
  ambiguous as the partiesâ€™ intent is not clearly discernable from the language
  of the SSA.Â  We believe the testimony in the record reasonably supports the
  masterâ€™s finding the parties intended the SSA to be in effect for so long as
  Premier was doing business at Barefoot.Â  Bradley Goulding, part owner and chief
  operating/financial officer of Premier Resorts International, testified Premier
  would not have entered into the loan-extension agreement without the SSA.Â  He further
  testified Premier was making a long-term investment in the Myrtle Beach area
  and would need the advantages offered by the SSA for as long as they were doing
  business at Barefoot.Â  Barbara Zimonja, co-owner and president of Premier
  Resorts International, testified she understood the SSA would be in effect as
  long as Premier was in business at Barefoot.Â  Zimonja also stated Barefoot was
  resistant to allowing Premier to have control of the tee time sheets, but
  eventually Barefoot agreed to the SSA.Â  
In an e-mail, Thomas Trefor, an attorney acting as general counsel
  for Barefoot at the time the SSA was executed, acknowledged the payoff of the
  loan did not affect the status of the SSA.Â  He further testified as follows:

  
    Q. Did you have any understanding as to how long the parties
      intended --- Whether they were contractual obligations or not --- how long
      these items mentioned in the Shared Services Agreement were to be enforced?
    A. My understanding was the intention here was that it be in
      perpetuity.Â  Iâ€™ll point out, however, that the reason that Barefoot --- or
      actually Larry Young and Danny Young were willing to agree to this provision,
      if it were contractually binding on them, was that they were really obligated
      to do it to Bank of America and, if they had engaged in this business at
      Barefoot, theyâ€™d be in default of the seventy-five million dollar loan.
    Q. When you say, â€œin perpetuity,â€ do you mean, â€œin
      perpetuity,â€ or do you mean, â€œperpetuity, so long as Barefoot is in business at
      the beach.â€
    . . .
    A. The way that itâ€™s drafted, it would appear to be a claim
      in true perpetuity.Â  In practice, if Barefoot is no longer in business, it
      becomes unenforceable.Â  
  

Larry Young, one of the principal owners of Barefoot, admitted
  the SSA was intended to help ensure the availability of golf tee times for
  Premier clients.Â  It logically follows Premier intended to accomplish this goal
  by having control of the tee time sheets as set forth in Paragraph 3(c) of the
  SSA for as long as they were doing business at Barefoot.
Larry Young and Danny Young, another principal owner in Barefoot,
  testified the SSA was to be re-evaluated periodically to see if it continued to
  be mutually beneficial to both parties.Â  However, their testimony indicated
  adjustments to the SSA were contemplated primarily with regard to the release
  dates for the blocked tee times.[4]Â  While Barefoot had little negotiating power in the agreement
  considering the need for the loan extension, they ultimately, and perhaps
  reluctantly, agreed to give control of the tee sheets to Premier.Â  The
  surrounding circumstances and the testimony in the record support the masterâ€™s
  finding that the agreement was to last â€œso long asâ€ Premier was doing business
  at Barefoot.
II. Barefootâ€™s
  Breach of the SSA
Next, Barefoot
  contends the master erred in finding it breached the SSA.Â  We disagree.Â  
Barefootâ€™s
  argument on lack of breach goes hand in hand with its arguments regarding the
  validity and duration of the SSA.Â  Barefoot does not deny it took control of
  the tee time sheets.Â  Barefoot simply contends this action provided notice to
  Premier that Barefoot intended to terminate the SSA.Â  See Carolina
    Cable Network v. Alert Cable TV, Inc., 316 S.C. 98, 102, 447 S.E.2d 199,
  201 (1994) (holding when no intent can be gleaned from the circumstances
  surrounding a contract, the court will find the contract to be terminable by
  either party given reasonable notice).Â  However, as previously discussed, we
  find the master did not err in determining the SSA was to be in place so long
  as Premier was doing business at Barefoot.Â  Consequently, the SSA was not
  terminable at will by either party, and Barefootâ€™s actions constituted a breach
  of the agreement.
III. Grant of
  Injunctive Relief
Barefoot also
  appeals the masterâ€™s issuance of a temporary injunction.Â  The injunctive order allowed
  Barefoot to retain control of the tee time sheets.Â  It also prevented Premier
  from booking any tee times outside of its blocked tee times until Premier had
  booked at least eighty-five percent of its blocked tee times.Â  Finally, the
  order required Barefoot to leave the required tee times blocked until sixty
  days prior at which time the time could be released.Â  
Upon
  the issuance of the masterâ€™s final order, the temporary injunction expired
  rendering this issue moot.Â  Therefore, we decline to address it. See Curtis
    v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 568, 549 S.E.2d 591, 597 (2001) (holding when a is moot).Â  Â Â 
IV. Damages
Next, Barefoot
  contends the trial court erred in awarding Premier $161,369 in damages when
  that award was not supported by the evidence.Â  We disagree.Â  
Barefoot appears
  to argue because Premier was paid the four percent commission on all tee times
  booked during the breach, Premier suffered no damages.Â  However, a plaintiff is
  allowed to offer evidence of lost profits so long as the circumstances indicate
  lost profits would have been within the contemplations of the parties at the
  time of the contract.Â  Drews Co. v. Ledwith-Wolfe Assocs., 296 S.C. 207,
  213, 371 S.E.2d 532, 535 (1988).Â  In this case, all the parties understood the
  control of the tee sheets would have substantial bearing on the success of
  Premier at Barefoot.Â  The parties would have also contemplated loss of control
  of the tee sheets would reduce the number of bookings by Premier.Â  The lost
  profits need not be reduced to a mathematical certainty to be recoverable.Â  Minter
    v. GOCT, Inc., 322 S.C. 525, 528, 473 S.E.2d 67, 70 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  However, the
  damages cannot be left to conjecture, guess, or speculation.Â  Id. 
Here, Premierâ€™s
  expert, Robert Mark Woodworth, testified he compared booking trends for Premier
  both â€œpre-breach and post-breach.â€Â  He then compared those figures with Premier
  bookings made during the breach when Barefoot had control of the tee time
  sheets.Â  Woodworth testified he then compared Premierâ€™s performance during the
  breach against other similar businesses in the area.Â  Using all of that data,
  he arrived at the conclusion Premier lost package golf commission income in the
  amount of $79,970 and non-package golf commission in the amount of $89,399. Â Woodworthâ€™s
  testimony established Premierâ€™s lost profits to a reasonable degree of
  certainty providing evidence to support the masterâ€™s award.
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Retention
  of Jurisdiction
Finally,
  Barefoot argues the master erred in retaining jurisdiction â€œfor the purpose of
  compliance with this Order and with the provisions of the Shared Services
  Agreement, and for determining such issues as may arise thereunder.â€Â  This
  issue was not raised to the trial court in its motion to alter or amend the
  judgment.Â  Therefore this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356
  S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003) (holding
  issues not raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not
  be considered on appeal).Â  
For all of the
  foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
SHORT
  and KONDUROS, J.J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Barefoot is equally
  owned by Barefoot Golf Club, LLC and Legends Barefoot, LLC (â€œLegends Barefootâ€).
[3] We have
  combined Appellantâ€™s Issues 1 and 2.
[4] Danny Young
  testified he had negotiated with Bradley Goulding for the unbooked blocked tee
  times to be released ninety days in advance so they could be booked through
  other avenues.Â  However, the SSA contained a sixty-day provision.Â  Young stated
  Goulding assured him at the signing of the SSA that the timing of the releases
  could be reviewed and adjusted periodically as needed.Â

PER CURIAM:Â  Betty Donald appeals the family courtâ€™s termination

    v. Vance, 287 S.C. 615, 618, 340 S.E.2d 554, 555 (Ct. App. 1986) (finding
  living with another, whether it is with a live-in lover, a relative, or a
  platonic housemate, changes oneâ€™s circumstances and alters his or her required

Accordingly,
  the family courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.[1]

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent
				v.
				Leroy McGrier, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-338
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed July 7,
  2008 
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender LaNelle C. DuRant, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				John Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Leroy McGrier challenges the trial judgeâ€™s order revoking ninety days for
  violating the conditions of the Community Supervision Program (CSP).Â  McGrier
  contends application of the CSP statute, section 24-21-560(D) of the South
  Carolina Code, is unconstitutional because it resulted in the imposition of a
  greater sentence than his original sentence.Â  We reverse.[1]Â  Â Â 
FACTS
McGrier was sentenced to three concurrent
  prison terms of three years each.Â  After serving thirty-two months of the
  thirty-six month sentence, McGrier was released to the South Carolina
  Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services (the Department) and
  entered the CSP.Â  McGrier was scheduled to end participation in the CSP on May
  3, 2004.
In February of 2004, the trial judge found McGrier willfully
  violated the terms of the CSP and revoked four months, remanding McGrier back
  to the custody of the South Carolina Department of Corrections.Â  After serving
  this sentence, McGrier was again released to CSP and assigned an ending date of
  June 22, 2006.Â  In April of 2005, the trial judge again found McGrier had
  violated the conditions of the CSP and sentenced McGrier to six months imprisonment.
  Â On April 3, 2006, the trial judge again found McGrier in violation of the
  terms and conditions of the CSP and ordered McGrier held in jail until he was
  accepted into an inpatient substance abuse treatment program. 
On October 26, 2006, the trial judge held another hearing on
  McGrierâ€™s alleged violations of the CSP.Â  McGrier argued the potential one-year
  incarceration for the violations amounted to the imposition of a new criminal
  sentence and violated his constitutional rights by not affording him the rights
  guaranteed to a criminal defendant.Â  On October 30, 2006, the trial judge found
  McGrier in violation of the CSP, revoked McGrierâ€™s CSP, and sentenced him to ninety
  days.Â  McGrier appealed to this court.
On January 27, 2007, McGrier was again released to the CSP.Â  On
  April 2, 2007, he appeared before the trial judge for alleged violations and
  raised the same constitutional challenge.Â  The trial judge revoked McGrierâ€™s CSP
  and ordered McGrier to serve six months.Â  McGrier appealed and the South
  Carolina Supreme Court reversed.Â  See State v. McGrier #2,
  Op. No. 26489 (S.C. Sup. Ct. refiled June 23, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 26
  at 24).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appealing the
  October 30, 2006 revocation and sentence, McGrier argues the trial judge erred
  in not finding section 24-21-460(D) of the South Carolina Code unconstitutional
  as applied to him.Â  Based on the supreme courtâ€™s analysis in McGrier #2,
  we agree.

	The CSP statute
  provides: 
	
		The maximum aggregate amount of time the
  prisoner may be required to serve when sentenced for successive revocations may
  not exceed an amount of time equal to the length of incarceration imposed for
  the original â€œno parole offense.â€ The original term of incarceration does not
  include any portion of a suspended sentence.
	


  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-560(D)
  (2007).Â  In McGrier #2, the supreme court stated:

	We now read this language as limiting the total amount of time an inmate could be incarcerated
  after a CSP revocation to be the length of the remaining balance of the sentence
  for the â€˜no parole offense.â€™ Based on this interpretation, a circuit court may
  not impose a sentence for a CSP revocation that would result in an inmate being
  incarcerated for an aggregate period of time that extended beyond the
  unsuspended portion of the original sentence. Thus, assuming an inmate has
  served at least eighty-five percent of the unsuspended portion of his original
  sentence, an inmate whose CSP is revoked is limited to serving an amount of
  time equal to the remaining fifteen percent balance of this sentence. 

McGrier #2 at 36.Â  As McGrier has served eighty-five percent of
  the original, three-year term of imprisonment and has served CSP revocation
  time of more than the time remaining on his original sentence, the decision of
  the trial judge is
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1]  We
  decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
