THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Hobbithouser,
      LLC, Appellant,
				v.
				Thomas L. Crosby,
      Jr., J & A Construction, and Joe A. Daves, Respondents,
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
S. Jackson Kimball, Master-In-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. Â 2008-UP-339
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed July 7, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Charles B. Baxley, of Lugoff, for Appellant.
				Daniel D. Dâ€™Agostino, of York, for Respondents and
				Thomas L. Crosby, Jr., pro se, of Matthews.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this action to foreclose a real estate mortgage, Hobbithouser, LLC (Hobbithouser)
  appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s finding that Thomas L. Crosby, Jr.â€™s payments on
  two promissory notes extinguished the notes and the related mortgage.Â  We affirm.[1] Â Â 
FACTS
On
  October 13, 1999, Crosby secured personal loans made to him by Carolina First
  Bank (Carolina First) by mortgaging approximately 164 acres in York County (York Property).Â  Subsequently, in an unrelated action, J & A Construction,
  Inc. obtained and recorded a judgment against Crosby.Â  Crosby failed to pay the
  judgment and the sheriff levied on the York Property.Â  On July 10, 2002, after
  two execution sales, the sheriff deeded the York Property to J & A
  Construction, the high bidder at both sales. 
After
  the York Property was levied, but prior to the execution sales, Crosby executed two promissory notes to Carolina First.Â  The first note (Note One), in the
  amount of $374,307.77, refinanced the original loan from October 1999 and was
  secured by the York Property.Â  The second note (Note Two), in the amount of
  $153,071.71, was cross-collateralized by the October 1999 mortgage on the York
  Property.Â  
On
  October 21, 2003 and November 28, 2003, more than a year after J & A
  Construction acquired the York Property, Crosby, using his personal funds, paid
  Carolina First in full for both notes.Â  Thereafter, on December 3, 2003,
  Carolina First assigned Note One, Note Two, and the October 1999 mortgage to
  Hobbithouser, a South Carolina corporation in which Crosby owns an eighty
  percent interest.Â  The assignment was subsequently filed on June 14, 2004. 
Meanwhile,
  on November 24, 2003, Crosby wrote a check to himself from the Hobbithouser
  account in the amount of $1,339,129.80 when Hobbithouserâ€™s account contained approximately
  $200.Â  The next day, Crosby made a deposit from his personal account into the Hobbithouser
  account in the exact same amount as written on the check.[2]Â  
Sometime
  after the York Property was deeded to J & A Construction and the notes and
  mortgage were assigned to Hobbithouser, Hobbithouser claimed J & A
  Construction failed to timely make interest payments on the notes.Â  On December
  22, 2005, Hobbithouser filed this action against Crosby, J & A Construction,
  and Joe A. Daves to foreclose the mortgage on the York Property.Â  After a non-jury
  trial, the master denied Hobbithouserâ€™s claim for foreclosure of the mortgage
  and directed the clerk of court to satisfy the mortgage.Â  The master also
  denied Hobbithouserâ€™s motion to reconsider.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to foreclose a real estate mortgage is an
  action in equity.â€Â  BB&T of South Carolina v. Kidwell, 350 S.C. 382,
  387, 565 S.E.2d 316, 319 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In an action in equity, we may
  review the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Smith v. Barr, 375 S.C. 157, 160, 650 S.E.2d 486, 488 (Ct.
  App. 2007).Â  However, we need not disregard the factual findings of the master,
  who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to judge their
  credibility.Â  Id.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.  Payments to Carolina First
Hobbithouser
  argues the master erred in finding Crosbyâ€™s payments to Carolina First
  extinguished his debt.Â  We disagree.
In Jeffcoat
  v. Morris, the court considered whether a receiver of a debtor, who
  purchased a debtorâ€™s note by paying off the debt, could sue the co-maker of the
  debtorâ€™s note.Â  300 S.C. 526, 389 S.E.2d 159 (Ct. App. 1989), overruled by United Carolina Bank v. Caroprop, 316 S.C. 1, 446 S.E.2d 415 (1994).[3]Â 
  After reviewing North Carolina and Virginia case law, the court held â€œpayment
  of a note by a maker, or an appointed receiver of the maker, operates to
  extinguish the note, discharging the liability of any co-makers on the note.â€Â  Id. at 529, 389 S.E.2d at 161.Â  The court reasoned that â€œ[t]o allow a maker of a
  note, or one who stands in the shoes of that person, to acquire an assignment
  of the note and then sue his co-makers on the note would open the doors to
  possible abuse and sharp dealing.â€Â  Id. 
Similarly,
  in Ives v. Rutland, a purchaser of property took the property subject to
  a mortgage, paid the bank in full for the mortgage, and then rather than
  satisfying the mortgage, requested the bank assign it to him.Â  The court held
  the mortgage â€œbecame a dead paperâ€ when the purchaser paid it off, thus there
  were no rights to assign.Â  135 S.C. 173, 182, 133 S.E. 539, 541 (1926). Â See
    also 59 C.J.S. Mortgages Â§ 460 (1998) (stating that payment of a mortgage
  debt generally discharges the mortgage and terminates the mortgageeâ€™s rights).
Here,
  Crosby paid off his debt in full and then secured an assignment to
  Hobbithouser, a company in which he owned an eighty percent interest.Â  In
  accordance with South Carolina jurisprudence, Crosbyâ€™s two notes and mortgage
  were extinguished when he, as the sole debtor on the notes and mortgage, paid
  the debts in full.Â  Once the debts were paid, the mortgage was satisfied and
  there were no rights to assign to Hobbithouser.Â  Therefore, J & A
  Constructionâ€™s judgment lien assumed the status of a first lien on the real
  property, and J & A Constructionâ€™s purchase of the property at the
  execution sale was free and clear from the prior lien of the mortgage.Â  
II.  Agent of Hobbithouser
Hobbithouser
  also contends the master erred in finding Crosby acted in an individual
  capacity when he paid off his debts because he was acting as an agent for
  Hobbithouser.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review.Â  
At
  trial and in its motion to reconsider, Hobbithouser argued Crosby made the
  payment on its behalf; however, it did not specifically raise any agency
  arguments.Â  See Collins Entmâ€™t Corp. v. Coats & Coats Rental
    Amusement, 368 S.C. 410, 418, 629 S.E.2d 635, 639 (2006) (finding a
  general, non-specific argument that does not encompass the specific grounds
  raised on appeal does not preserve the issue).Â  Accordingly, this argument is
  not preserved for our review.Â  
III.  Defense
  of Avoidance
Hobbithouser
  argues the master erred in admitting evidence constituting the defense of
  avoidance because J & A Construction failed to plead it as a defense.Â  This
  issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Â Â 
Hobbithouser did
  not make this argument to the master.Â  Because this argument was not raised to
  or ruled upon by the master, it is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder
    Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (stating an
  argument raised for the first time on appeal is not preserved for appellate
  review).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, the order on appeal is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1]  We
  decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  Crosby testified the money he deposited was
  payment to him from an unrelated land sale. 
[3]  Jeffcoat was overruled â€œat least to the
  extent that it prevents a mortgagor from being equitably subrogated to rights
  of a mortgagee.â€ Â Williams v. Sandman, 187 F.3d 379, 382 n.2 (4th Cir.
  1999).

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Blondell Terry, Respondent,
        v.
        Emory Brown and
          Virginia R. Hamilton as Delinquent Tax Collector, Defendants,
        Of whom Emory
          Brown is Appellant.
      
    
  


 
Appeal From Berkeley County
Robert E. Watson, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-413
  Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed July 21,
2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        Ronald L. Richter, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Ernie L. Mixon, of Monks Corner, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Emory
  Brown appeals the order of the master finding the tax sale of Blondell Terryâ€™s
  property was void.Â  Specifically, Brown maintains the tax sale notices did not
  violate the statutory requirements and Terry waived her rights to challenge the
  tax sale by accepting the surplus proceeds of the sale.Â  We affirm.[1] Â Â 
FACTS
Terry
  failed to timely pay her taxes for the year 2001.Â  Pursuant to statutory
  authority, the county mailed Terry a notice of delinquency.Â  When thirty days passed
  with no response, the county mailed Terry a certified notice with restrictive
  delivery, which was returned unclaimed after three attempts to notify Terry.Â  Because
  Terry did not claim her notice, the county posted a tax sale notice on Terryâ€™s
  property.Â  The county also advertised the sale of the property in the local
  newspaper for three consecutive weeks.Â  Brown was the successful bidder at the
  tax sale and obtained the tax deed for the property on March 18, 2004.Â  After
  the tax sale, Terry was notified by mail she was entitled to a check for the surplus
  proceeds of the sale of her property, which she picked up and deposited into
  her bank account.
After
  the tax sale, Terry brought an action to set aside the tax deed based on
  defects in the sale.Â  On June 23, 2006, the matter was referred to the master
  and the case was tried on October 3, 2006.Â  During the trial, Terry testified
  she was unaware the check came from the sale of her property.Â  Terry also
  testified she never received notice by mail or posting that her house was going
  to be sold at a tax sale.Â  Terryâ€™s son, who lived with his mother, also
  testified he never saw a posting on the land.Â  During the trial, the defendants
  did not present a copy of the notice of delinquent property taxes mailed to
  Terry.Â  The defendants also did not present any testimony from the employees
  who posted the notice on Terryâ€™s land or from the clerk who gave Terry the
  check from the sale of her land.
On
  March 1, 2007, the master entered a final order finding the tax sale void for
  defects in the notices that created artificial deadlines and contradicted the
  statutory language.Â  The master also found Terry did not waive her rights to
  challenge the tax sale even though she accepted and deposited a check for the
  surplus proceeds from the sale of her property.Â  Brown filed a Rule 59(e),
  SCRCP, motion to reconsider, which was denied after a hearing on the motion.Â  This
  appeal followed.Â  Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œOur scope of review for a case heard by a [m]aster
  permits us to determine facts in accordance with our own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Smith v. Barr, 375 S.C. 157, 160, 650
  S.E.2d 486, 488 (Ct. App. 2007); see also Folk v. Thomas, 344
  S.C. 77, 80, 543 S.E.2d 556, 557 (2001) (finding an action to set aside a tax
  deed rests in equity, thus, an appellate court may take its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence). Â However, we are not required to disregard the
  factual findings of the master, who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a
  better position to judge their credibility.Â  Smith, 375 at 160, 650
  S.E.2d at 488.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.Â  Delinquent
  Tax Notices
Brown
  alleges the master erred by ruling the tax sale notices contained artificial
  deadlines for the payment of taxes, rendering the tax sale void.Â  We disagree.Â  
Section 12-51-40 of
  the South Carolina Code provides the procedure for notifying delinquent taxpayers
  that property will be sold to collect owed tax monies.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  12-51-40 (Supp. 2007).Â  Tax sales of property pursuant to the statute must be
  conducted in strict compliance with its requirements.Â  In re Ryan Inv. Co.,
  335 S.C. 392, 395, 517 S.E.2d 692, 693 (1999).Â  In Rives v. Bulsa, 325
  S.C. 287, 293, 478 S.E.2d 878, 881 (Ct. App. 1996), the court determined the
  notice provision in the statute is a jurisdictional requirement:

  [T]he
    general law is that where a statute requires as a condition precedent to
    foreclosing a taxpayerâ€™s rights in property sold for taxes that he be given
    notice of his right to redeem, such a requirement is generally regarded as
    jurisdictional, and therefore, the ownerâ€™s right of redemption cannot be cut
    off unless the required notice is given.Â  

Â â€œFailure to give the
  required notice is a fundamental defect in the tax proceedings which renders the
  proceedings absolutely void.â€Â  Id.
Section 12-51-40(b)
  mandates â€œ[a]ll delinquent notices shall specify that if the taxes,
  assessments, penalties, and costs are not paid before a subsequent sales
    date, the property must be duly advertised and sold for delinquent property
  taxes, assessments, penalties, and costs.â€ (emphasis added). Â Section 12-51-40(c)
  further provides if a certified mail notice is returned, a notice must be
  posted â€œat one or more conspicuous places on the premises, in the case of real
  estate, reading: â€˜Seized by person officially charged with the collection of
  delinquent taxes of (name of political subdivision) to be sold for delinquent
  taxes.â€™â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-40 (Supp. 2007).
In Hawkins v.
  Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 577 S.E.2d 202 (2003), the supreme court
  held the two notices at issue created artificial deadlines for payment, which contradicted
  the statutory language.Â  The language in the first notice stated, â€œ[i]f not
  paid on or before 31 August this property will be duly advertised and sold for
  delinquent taxes as described above on the first Monday in October this year.â€Â  Id. at 37, 577 S.E.2d at 205.Â  The second notice stated the property
  was subject to a sale on October 2, but also provided â€œ[a]ll tax payments must
  be received by September 15, 1995 to avoid your name and property being
  advertised in The Beaufort Gazette and The Island Packet.â€Â  Id.Â  
The supreme
  court found the August and September deadlines were artificial because the
  sales date was October 2, and the deadlines gave the impression the taxes had
  to be paid weeks before the sale date.Â  Id. at 38, 577 S.E.2d at 206.Â 
  The court added â€œthe statute does not provide that the County set a date, other
  than the sales date, after which the taxpayer can no longer pay his delinquent
  taxes before the County can begin advertising.â€Â  Id.
Here,
  the notice mailed to Terry set the date of sale for her property as November,
  4, 2002; however, the notice also provided, â€œif the outstanding taxes,
  assessments, penalties and costs due on the property described below are not
  paid before October 10, 2002, the property must be advertised for sale in a
  newspaper of general circulation.â€Â  The additional language in the notice gave
  the impression Terry had to pay the taxes weeks before the date of sale, which created
  an artificial deadline for payment of taxes before the set sales date of November
  4, 2002.Â  Additionally, the notice posted on Terryâ€™s property set the sale date
  as November, 4, 2002, but contained additional language stating â€œif not paid by
  October 10, 2002 a total cost $100.00 will accrue [for expenses related to the
  levy, seizure, and sale of the property].â€Â  This language also created an
  artificial deadline.Â  
Therefore,
  because the tax sale notices contained additional language and dates other than
  the sales date, they created artificial deadlines that contradicted the
  statutory language.Â  See id.Â  Thus, the master correctly found
  the tax sale was void.
II.Â 
  Surplus Proceeds
Â Brown
  also asserts Terry waived her right to object to the sale by accepting and
  depositing a check for the surplus proceeds of the tax sale.Â  We disagree.
â€œA
  waiver is a voluntary and intentional abandonment or relinquishment of a known
  right.â€Â  Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas Horizontal Prop. Regime, 307
  S.C. 339, 344, 415 S.E.2d 384, 387 (1992).Â  â€œGenerally, the party claiming
  waiver must show that the party against whom waiver is asserted possessed, at
  the time, actual or constructive knowledge of his rights or of all the material
  facts upon which they depended.â€Â  Id. at 344, 415 S.E.2d at 387-88. Â â€œThe
  burden of proof of waiver is on the party asserting it.â€Â  NationsBank v.
    Scott Farm, 320 S.C. 299, 303, 465 S.E.2d 98, 100 (Ct. App. 1995).
The
  master found Brown did not present any credible evidence to establish Terry
  intended to waive her rights to challenge the tax sale.Â  Terry testified she
  was unaware the money was from the tax sale of her property.Â  Brown did not
  present any testimony to rebut Terryâ€™s testimony.Â  Therefore, the master
  correctly found Terry did not waive her claims against Brown regarding the sale
  of her property.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the order of the master is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
C.J., and SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        L.A. Barrier
          & Son, Inc., Respondent,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Transportation, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Richland County
  Â Paige J. Gossett, Administrative Law
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â Â  2008-UP-418
Heard June 3, 2008 â€“ Filed July 21, 2008 

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Deborah Brooks Durden, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        John Julius Pringle, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The
  South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) appeals from the
  Administrative Law Courtâ€™s (ALC) order requiring SCDOT to grant L.A. Barrier
  & Son, Inc.â€™s (L.A. Barrier) application for certification as a
  Disadvantaged Business Enterprise (DBE).Â  We reverse.Â  
BACKGROUND
The
  present case concerns L.A. Barrierâ€™s application to SCDOT for certification as
  a DBE.Â  Federal regulation requires states that receive federal highway funding
  to implement DBE programs.Â Â  49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.3 (2007).Â  DBE programs were
  created to ensure nondiscrimination in the award of Department of
  Transportation contracts and to provide a level playing field for eligible
  businesses.Â  49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.1 (2007).Â  As a recipient of federal highway
  funding, South Carolina created its DBE program through section 12-28-2930 of
  the South Carolina Code (2000), requiring SCDOT to expend a minimum amount of
  state source highway funds through contracts with DBEs.Â  
South
  Carolinaâ€™s DBE program is regulated under
  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-700 to 63-718 (Supp. 2007).Â  Under 25A S.C. Code
  Ann. Reg. 63-702, to be eligible for participation in both the federal and
  state DBE programs in South Carolina, a firm must first be certified by SCDOT
  â€œas a bona fide [DBE] pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in
  Regulations 63-703 and 63-704 and 49 C.F.R. Part 26.â€Â  The South Carolina
  regulations incorporate the federal standards for determining DBE status found
  in 49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.Â  
Under
  the applicable regulations, a DBE is defined as a for-profit small business,
  which is owned and controlled by one or more individuals who are both socially
  and economically disadvantaged.Â  49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.5 (2007); 25A S.C. Code Ann.
  Reg. 63-701 (Supp. 2007).Â  To meet the ownership requirement, â€œa firm must be
  at least 51 percent owned by socially and economically disadvantaged
  individuals.â€Â  49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.69(b) (2007). Â Under the regulations, women are
  presumed to be socially and economically disadvantaged individuals but must still
  show they have a net worth not exceeding $750,000 to qualify as a disadvantaged
  individual.Â  49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.67(a)(1) - (2)(i) (2007).Â  In this appeal, SCDOT
  argues L.A. Barrier is not entitled to certification as a DBE because it does
  not meet the ownership requirements of 49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.69 (2007).Â  
FACTS
L.A. Barrier is a
  closely held corporation in the business of hauling and transporting road
  construction materials. Â L.A. Barrier is one of three corporations owned by
  members of the Barrier and Tyson families in Lexington, South Carolina.Â  The
  other two corporations are B & T Sand Co., Inc. (B & T Sand) and B
  & T Investments, Inc. (B & T Investments). 
Prior
  to July 1, 2006, Betty Tyson (Betty) owned 25,000 shares of L.A. Barrierâ€™s
  stock, while Bill Barrier (Bill) and Bob Barrier (Bob) each owned 12,000
  shares, and Electa Barrier (Electa) owned 1,000 shares.Â  On or about July 1,
  2006, Betty transferred all 25,000 of her shares without consideration to Lisa
  Tyson (Lisa), who is married to Bettyâ€™s son, Joel Tyson (Joel).Â  Also on or
  about July 1, 2006, Electa transferred 500 shares to Lisa for $4,210. Â Lisa
  paid for the shares using funds from a joint checking account she shared with
  Joel.Â  At the time of the transfers, Bettyâ€™s net worth exceeded $750,000, so
  she no longer qualified as a disadvantaged individual.Â  After the two
  transfers, Lisa, the new president of L.A. Barrier, owned fifty-one percent of
  L.A. Barrierâ€™s stock.Â Â  
On July 31, 2006,
  L.A. Barrier applied to SCDOT for certification as a DBE.Â  Subsequently, in a letter
  dated December 8, 2006, SCDOT denied the application.Â  The letter outlined
  SCDOTâ€™s reasons for denying certification, including: (1) Betty was involved in
  an affiliate firm through her ownership of stock in B & T Sand; (2) Betty
  was engaged in a business relationship with L.A. Barrier as its landlord
  because she owned a one-half interest in the building and property where L.A.
  Barrier operates; and (3) Joel had not renounced his interest in the ownership
  interest of the 500 shares Lisa purchased using funds from their joint checking
  account.Â  After receiving SCDOTâ€™s letter, L.A. Barrier requested a contested
  case hearing before the ALC.
Between
  the time of SCDOTâ€™s denial of certification and the contested case hearing,
  Betty and Joel took several steps to correct the errors causing SCDOTâ€™s denial
  of L.A. Barrierâ€™s application.Â  On April 9, 2007, Betty transferred her
  one-half interest in the building and real estate where L.A. Barrier operates
  to Tommy Tyson (Tommy), her husband, without consideration.Â  On the same day,
  she transferred all of her stock in B & T Sand to Joel, her son, without
  consideration.Â  Lastly, Joel signed a document renouncing his interest in the
  500 shares of stock purchased with funds from the joint checking account he
  shared with Lisa. 
The contested case
  hearing was held on May 1 and 2, 2007.Â  Ultimately, the ALC determined L.A.
  Barrier qualified for DBE certification and ordered SCDOT to grant L.A.
  Barrierâ€™s application.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section 1-23-610 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007)
  sets forth the standard of review when the Court of Appeals
  is sitting in review of a decision by the ALC on appeal
  from an administrative agency.Â  â€œThe review of the administrative law judgeâ€™s
  order must be confined to the record.â€Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-610(C). Â Under section 1-23-610(C), the Court of Appeals

  may affirm the decision or
    remand the case for further proceedings; or [the Court] may reverse or modify
    the decision if the substantive rights of the petitioner [have] been prejudiced
    because [] the finding, conclusion, or decision is:
  
    (a) in violation of constitutional or statutory
      provisions;
    (b) in excess of the statutory authority of the
      agency;
    (c) made upon
      unlawful procedure;
    (d)
      affected by other error of law;
    (e) clearly erroneous in view of the reliable,
      probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record; or
    (f) arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse
      of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.
  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  LAW/ANALYSIS
SCDOT
  argues L.A. Barrier does not qualify as a DBE because Joel did not effectively
  renounce his interest in the 500 shares of stock Lisa acquired with funds from
  their joint checking account, and as a result, Lisa does not have sole
  ownership of fifty-one percent of the firm.Â  Specifically, SCDOT argues: (1)
  while Joel renounced his interest in the stock, he did not also renounce his
  interest in the jointly held assets used to purchase the stock, and (2) the
  document whereby Joel renounced his interest in the stock was not included in
  L.A. Barrierâ€™s application for certification.Â Â  We agree.Â  
Under
  49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.69(i) (2007), when marital assets are used to acquire a
  disadvantaged individualâ€™s ownership interest in a business or firm, the finder
  of fact must apply the following rules: 

  (1)
    When marital assets (other than the assets of the business in question), held
    jointly or as community property by both spouses, are used to acquire the
    ownership interest asserted by one spouse, [the entity determining DBE status]
    must deem the ownership interest in the firm to have been acquired by that
    spouse with his or her own individual resources, provided that the other spouse
    irrevocably renounces and transfers all rights in the ownership interest in the
    manner sanctioned by the laws of the state in which either spouse or the firm
    is domiciled. . . . 
  (2) A
    copy of the document legally transferring and renouncing the other spouseâ€™s
    rights in the jointly owned or community assets used to acquire an ownership
    interest in the firm must be included as part of the firmâ€™s application for DBE
    certification.

Looking at the language of the section as a whole, it
  is clear the purpose of the regulation is to ensure the ownership interest is
  solely attributable to the disadvantaged individual for the purpose of
  determining whether the firm meets the fifty-one percent threshold of 49 C.F.R.
  Â§ 26.69(b).Â  While 49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.69(i) sets forth the general rule that some
  portion of the ownership interest is attributable to the disadvantaged
  individualâ€™s spouse if marital assets are used to purchase the ownership
  interest, the section also provides an exception when the spouse has renounced
  his or her portion of the ownership interest.Â  
However, subsections (1) and (2) of 49 C.F.R. Â§
  26.69(i) address the method of renunciation differently.Â  While subsection (1)
  mandates that the ALC must treat an ownership interest as being acquired with the
  individualâ€™s own funds when the spouse has renounced any rights in the ownership
    interest, subsection (2) refers to renunciation of the assets used
  to acquire the ownership interest.Â  
SCDOT first argues Joel must have renounced his
  interest in the assets used to acquire the stock in addition to the stock
  itself to comply with the terms of 49 C.F.R. 26.69(i).Â  We agree. 
When the terms of a statute are clear, the court must
  apply those terms according to their literal meaning. Â Paschal v. State
    Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436, 454 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1995). Â This Court
  cannot construe a statute without regard to its ordinary and plain meaning and
  may not resort to a forced interpretation in an effort to expand or limit the
  scope of a statute. Â Berkebile v. Outen, 311 S.C. 50, 55, 426 S.E.2d 760,
  763 (1993).Â  Furthermore, â€œthe construction of a statute by the agency charged
  with its administration will be accorded the most respectful consideration and
  will not be overruled absent compelling reasons.â€ Â Dunton v. S.C. Bd. of
    Examâ€™rs in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987).Â  
L.A. Barrier argues a renunciation of the 500 shares
  of stock is sufficient to comply with the statute; however, a plain reading of
  the statute demonstrates otherwise.Â  Because Lisa purchased the 500 shares of
  stock with funds from Joel and Lisaâ€™s joint checking account, the statute
  mandates that SCDOT apply 49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.69(i).Â  The plain language of 49
  C.F.R. Â§ 26.69(i) requires the non-disadvantaged spouse to renounce both the rights in the ownership interest and the rights in the jointly owned assets
  used to acquire the ownership interest.Â  See 49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.69(i)(1) - (2).Â  
Although Joel may have satisfied 49 C.F.R. Â§
  26.69(i)(1) by renouncing his interest in the stock by the date of the hearing,
  he failed to satisfy 49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.69(i)(2) by never renouncing his ownership
  interest in the joint checking account.Â  While we recognize the 500 shares of
  stock represent a very small portion of the overall ownership interest, the
  fact remains without a full and proper renunciation, these shares must be
  attributed in part to Joel, such that Lisaâ€™s ownership interest falls short of
  the fifty-one percent ownership requirement set forth in 49 C.F.R. Â§ 26.69(b).Â 
  Because L.A. Barrier did not meet the eligibility requirements of 49 C.F.R. Â§
  26, SCDOT properly denied its application for certification as a DBE.Â  See 25A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 63-703(A) (stating SCDOT â€œwill certify a firm as a bona
  fide DBE under the State or Federal DBE Program if [SCDOT] determines that the
  firm meets the eligibility requirements of 49 C.F.R. Part 26â€).
In
  light of our holding on this issue, it is not necessary to address SCDOTâ€™s
  remaining arguments.Â  Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 335 S.C.
  598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (providing that an appellate court need
  not address additional issues if the resolution of another issue is
  dispositive). 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, the ALCâ€™s order is
REVERSED.
WILLIAMS, THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT

  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State Respondent,
				v.
				Damon Jacquise
      Jones, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-424
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed July 23,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka,
  Senior Assisant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia;
  and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Damon Jacquise Jones (Jones)
  appeals his conviction for murder, contending the trial court erred by not
  admitting his videotaped interrogation into evidence.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In late 2005, Jones
  stood trial for the murder of Sigida Long (Sigida).Â  Jones testified to the
  events surrounding this incident.Â  According to his testimony, on February 25,
  2005, Jones, Ben Foster (Foster), and Gregg Hardy (Hardy) were at Hardyâ€™s
  sisterâ€™s house drinking beer.Â  Subsequently, Jones drove Hardy and Foster to Jonesâ€™
  grandmotherâ€™s house to drop off Foster.Â  Upon arrival, Hardy helped Foster, who
  was intoxicated, to the door.Â  While Jones remained in the car, the victim,
  Sigida, and his brother, Atiba Long (Atiba), drove into their driveway next
  door.[1] Sigida and Atiba then exited their vehicle and knocked on the door of Jonesâ€™
  grandmotherâ€™s house in an attempt to get Foster to come outside.Â  Unable to get
  Foster outside, Sigida walked over to Jonesâ€™ vehicle and pulled Jones out of
  the car.Â Â Â  
Sigida hit Jones in
  the head a few times, causing Jones to fall back into his vehicle.Â  Jones then
  grabbed a gun out of the glove compartment, exited the vehicle, cocked the
  weapon and told Sigida and Atiba to back up.Â  Sigida rushed Jones, and a
  struggle ensued.Â  During the struggle, the gun discharged, striking and fatally
  wounding Sigida.Â  Jones then ran into his grandmotherâ€™s house and instructed
  his aunt to call the police.Â  
Following the shooting, Sergeant Christopher Taylor,
  of the Spartanburg Public Safety Department, questioned Jones about the
  incident, and this interrogation was videotaped.Â  After Jones testified about
  the events of the incident and his distraught and overwhelmed emotional state
  following the shooting, Jonesâ€™ counsel attempted to admit the videotaped
  interrogation into evidence.Â  The State objected to the videotapeâ€™s admission,
  characterizing the evidence as self-serving hearsay.Â  Additionally, the State
  argued because it did not introduce any statements from the videotape, Jones
  could not introduce it to bolster his testimony.Â  The trial court sustained the
  Stateâ€™s objection, finding Jonesâ€™ statements on the tape â€œexactly or quite
  similarâ€ to his testimony.Â Â Â  
Defense counsel
  later called Hardy to testify.Â  Hardy gave his recollection of events and also
  described Jones as being â€œin shockâ€ and â€œhystericalâ€ following the shooting.Â  
The
  jury found Jones guilty of murder, and he was sentenced to life imprisonment.Â 
  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases,
  the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€Â  State v. Baccus,
  367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  â€œThe admission of evidence is
  within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed absent an
  abuse of discretion.â€Â  State v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 208, 631 S.E.2d
  262, 265 (2006).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s
  conclusions either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of
  law.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Jones
  contends the trial court erred by excluding his videotaped interrogation from
  evidence.Â  In the alternative, Jones argues the portion of the videotape prior
  to his interrogation is not hearsay and was, therefore, improperly excluded.Â 
  We disagree.
The
  improper exclusion of evidence is harmless when it is cumulative to other
  testimony in the record.Â  State v. Sapp, 366 S.C. 283, 294, 621 S.E.2d
  883, 888 (2005).Â  Thus, even if the exclusion of cumulative evidence is
  erroneous, it will not warrant a reversal by this Court.Â  State v. Pipkin,
  359 S.C. 322, 328, 597 S.E.2d 831, 834 (Ct. App. 2004).
At
  trial, Jones argued the shooting took place while he was acting in self-defense.Â 
  Jones testified as to the events surrounding the incident as well as his mental
  state following the shooting.Â  Additionally, Hardy gave his recollection of the
  incident and testified Jones was â€œin shockâ€ and â€œhystericalâ€ following the
  shooting.Â  
Due
  to this testimony, the videotape would have been merely cumulative to evidence
  in the record.Â  The statements on the videotape were found to be â€œexactly or
  quite similarâ€ to Jonesâ€™ testimony, and the jury was told multiple times about
  Jonesâ€™ mental state following the shooting.Â  Jonesâ€™ counsel sought to admit the
  videotape into evidence to corroborate Jonesâ€™ testimony rather than to present
  any new evidence to the jury.[2]Â 
  Because of its cumulative nature, even if the evidence was improperly excluded,
  the error was merely harmless.Â  See Sapp, 366 S.C. at 294, 621
  S.E.2d at 888 (finding the exclusion of evidence is harmless if it is
  cumulative to other testimony in the record).Â  
We
  find no reversible error in the exclusion of the videotape and, therefore, do
  not address whether each portion of the videotape was inadmissible hearsay.Â  See Hughes v. State, 367 S.C. 389, 408-09, 626 S.E.2d 805, 815 (2006)
  (finding appellate courts need not address remaining issues when determination
  of prior issue is dispositive).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.[3] 
WILLIAMS,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.Â  


[1] The Longs lived
  beside Jonesâ€™ grandmother.Â  
[2] We additionally
  note the State never made an issue of Jonesâ€™ statements on the videotape or his
  mental state following the shooting.Â  
[3] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â

				John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Frederick L. Harris, of Myrtle Beach; and George M. Hearn, Jr., of
  Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Jon Christopher Nobles (Husband) appeals the family court order granting Carie
  Nobles (Wife) a divorce, arguing the family court erred in its determination of
  marital property, valuation of special equity interests, and equitable division
  of the marital estate.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
I.  Background
Husband
  and Wife were high school sweethearts and became engaged while attending Clemson University.Â  Husband graduated from Clemson in December 1993, and obtained
  employment as a credit manager for Heilig-Myers Furniture in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  Husband and Wife married on May 20, 1995.Â  Shortly thereafter, Husband was
  transferred to Griffin, Georgia, as a Heilig-Myers store manager.Â  Wife graduated
  from Clemson in December 1995, and joined Husband in Griffin.Â  In July 1996,
  Husband was transferred to Jacksonville, Florida, where he eventually managed three
  Heilig-Myers stores and earned approximately $100,000 per year.Â  Wife also
  obtained employment in Jacksonville at the Florida Department of Health as a
  health educator earning $28,000 per year.
In early 2001, Husband lost his job with Heilig-Myers when the
  retail chain filed for bankruptcy.Â  Consequently, Husband and Wife returned to South Carolina to open a franchise furniture store in Myrtle Beach.Â  In March 2001, while
  making plans to leave Jacksonville, Wife became pregnant.Â  Approximately five months
  later, the parties moved to North Myrtle Beach and their first child, Sarah,
  was born in November 2001.Â  Following the birth of Sarah, Husband and Wife
  moved into a new home with financial contributions provided by Wifeâ€™s parents.Â  
II.  Noble Enterprises
  of the Carolinas
With the proceeds from the sale of their home in Jacksonville and
  Husbandâ€™s 401(k), the parties opened Norwalk: The Furniture Idea (Norwalk), a franchise, under the name Noble Enterprises of the Carolinas, LLC, the
  franchisee.Â  Based upon his management experience in the furniture business,
  Husband served as Norwalkâ€™s managing partner.Â  Husband, his mother and father,
  and Wife each owned a twenty-five percent interest in the business.Â  While Wife
  occasionally assisted with the business, she was primarily responsible for
  caring for the coupleâ€™s first child.Â  
After Norwalk opened, Husband began staying away from home and became
  less dedicated to his role as managing partner.Â  Consequently, Wife hired
  Pamela Burris as sales manager for Norwalk.Â  Due to Husbandâ€™s increasing
  unavailability, Burris became the de facto manager of the store.Â  By
  December 2005, Husband was working as a waiter and was no longer associated
  with Norwalk.Â  Shortly thereafter, Norwalk ceased operation.
III.  Termination of
  Marriage 
Husband began to withdraw from Wife in December 2003, arriving
  home from work no earlier than 8:00 p.m. and sometimes as late as 11:00 p.m.Â  While
  Wife expressed concern regarding Husbandâ€™s absence, he claimed work demanded
  the majority of his time.Â  Husband showed little emotion and continued to
  withdraw from the marriage when Wife became pregnant with the coupleâ€™s second
  child in April 2004.Â  Husband began devoting his time to conducting private,
  secretive activities on his computer, and would shut down the computer when
  Wife entered the room.Â  Although Husband denied having an affair, Wife
  discovered Husband was visiting various pornographic websites and corresponding
  with at least three women twenty to thirty times a day in various internet chat
  rooms. Â Wife also found suspicious text messages of an explicit nature on
  Husbandâ€™s phone and later found out Husband had rented a private post office
  box.Â  Soon thereafter, Husband began refusing Wifeâ€™s phone calls during the day
  and would not return home until Wife had gone to bed.Â  Husbandâ€™s appearance also
  began to change dramatically.Â  Husband joined Goldâ€™s Gym, hired a personal
  trainer, and spent a minimum of three hours every day at the gym even though
  his business was failing.Â  Husbandâ€™s financial excesses included an ongoing
  health club membership, massages, manicures, hair appointments, car washes, and
  lawn care.
On March 21, 2005, Wife confronted Husband regarding their marital
  problems.Â  In response, Husband requested Wife file for divorce and the parties
  subsequently separated.Â  Wife hired a private investigator who obtained proof
  of Husbandâ€™s relationship with Allison Sides, a fellow member of Goldâ€™s Gym.Â  Wife
  and Wifeâ€™s father also observed Husband on several occasions with Sides, including
  dinner dates and other social gatherings.Â  According to Husband, he engaged in
  sexual relations with Sides only after the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  
IV.  Post-Separation
  and Subsequent Proceedings
Since the separation, Wife and the coupleâ€™s children have continued
  to reside in the marital home.Â  Wife found employment and earns $2,092 gross
  per month.Â  Wife pays approximately $70 per month for the childrenâ€™s medical
  and dental insurance and $953 per month for daycare. Â Immediately after the separation,
  Husband resided with his parents and continued to work as a waiter.Â  However,
  Husband later moved to Jacksonville, Florida with his present girlfriend,
  Danelle Metz, where he still waits tables at a local restaurant.
Following Husbandâ€™s relocation to Jacksonville, Wife brought an
  action against Husband seeking a divorce on the ground of adultery, an award of
  separate support and maintenance, use and possession of the marital home,
  custody of the partiesâ€™ two children, child support, alimony, attorneysâ€™ fees,
  and restraining orders against disposing of assets and exposing the children to
  his romantic relationships.Â  In response, Husband counterclaimed for a mutual
  bar to alimony, equitable apportionment of the marital estate, a co-parenting
  arrangement, and an award of attorneysâ€™ fees and court costs.Â  
On August 22, 2005, the family court issued a temporary order awarding
  Wife primary custody of the children and use of the marital home.Â  The
  temporary order also required Husband pay child support in the amount of $198
  per month based upon his imputed income of $4,000.Â  In addition, Husband was
  ordered to pay $2,000 per month for Wifeâ€™s separate support and maintenance as
  well as $10,000 towards Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees.
Approximately one year later, the family court issued a final
  order awarding Wife a divorce on the ground of adultery and granting her primary
  custody of the partiesâ€™ two children.Â  In determining child support, the family
  court imputed a monthly income of $4,000 to Husband finding he was voluntarily underemployed and capable
  of earning more given his skills, experience, and expertise.Â  Based upon
  Husbandâ€™s imputed earnings of $4,000 per month, the family court ordered
  Husband to pay $1,114 in monthly child support.Â  With regards to equitable
  division, the family court valued the marital home at $230,000 and distributed
  sixty percent of the marital property to Wife.Â  In dividing the marital debt,
  the family court also noted Wife faced potential liability to the former family
  business based on an action brought against her by Noble Enterprises.Â  However,
  the family court ordered Husband to indemnify Wife against any judgment awarded
  in the pending lawsuit, finding any debt incurred by Noble Enterprises was â€œa
  direct result of Husbandâ€™s failure to dedicate himself to the business and the
  marriage . . . which he abandoned.â€Â  The family court further ordered Husband to
  pay Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees in the amount of $12,800.Â  Subsequently, Husband filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP,
  motion, which was denied.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an
  appeal from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find the
  facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Ex
    parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  However,
  this broad scope of review does not require the appellate court to disregard
  the findings of the family court.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540,
  615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  â€œNeither is the
  appellate court required to ignore the fact that the family court, who saw and
  heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and
  assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Id. at 540, 615
  S.E.2d at 102.  
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.  Husbandâ€™s Income
Husband
  argues the family court erred in imputing $4,000 per month income to him.Â 
  Specifically, Husband asserts the family court erred in finding he was
  voluntarily underemployed and capable of earning $4,000 per month based upon
  his skill, experience, and expertise.Â  We disagree.Â  
Our courts
  have held imputing income to a party who is voluntarily unemployed or
  underemployed is proper.Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 532, 599 S.E.2d
  114, 123 (2004); Penny v. Green, 357 S.C. 583, 592, 594 S.E.2d 171, 175
  (Ct. App. 2004).Â  To prove voluntary underemployment, â€œa parent seeking to
  impute income to the other parent need not establish a bad faith motivation to
  lower a support obligation.â€Â  Arnal v. Arnal, 371 S.C. 10, 13, 636
  S.E.2d 864, 866 (2006).Â  When â€œimput[ing] income to a parent who is unemployed
  or underemployed, the court should determine the employment potential and
  probable earning level of the parent based on that parentâ€™s recent work
  history, occupational qualifications, and prevailing job opportunities and
  earning levels in the community.â€Â  Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 449, 539
  S.E.2d 712, 714 (Ct. App. 2000); 27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A)(5)(B)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  â€œWhere a parent voluntarily lessens his or her earning capacity,
  this Court will closely scrutinize the facts to determine the parentâ€™s earning
  potential, rather than the parentâ€™s actual income.â€Â  Id.; see Camp
    v. Camp, 269 S.C. 173, 174-5, 236 S.E.2d 814, 815 (1977); Robinson v.
      Tyson, 319 S.C. 360, 363, 461 S.E.2d 397, 399 (Ct. App. 1995); see also Chastain v. Chastain, 289 S.C. 281, 283, 346 S.E.2d 33, 35 (Ct. App. 1986)
  (finding father with masterâ€™s degree voluntarily removed himself from the job
  market to attend law school and his earning potential was properly considered
  in calculating child support).
Here,
  Husband earned approximately
  $100,000 per year managing three Heilig-Myers stores.Â  The
  parties testified Husband earned at least $4,000 per month while he worked at Norwalk.Â  Also, Husband filed a loan application indicating he was earning $5,000 per
  month.Â  After Husband abandoned Norwalk, he began working as a waiter in Myrtle Beach.Â  A short time later, Husband moved to Florida with his current girlfriend
  where he also works as a waiter.Â  Husband testified he has applied for jobs,
  but has not found one because he is only looking for upper-level management
  jobs.Â  Husband has the ability to get a higher paying job than working as a
  part-time waiter because of his experience and knowledge of the furniture
  business; however, he has chosen to remain underemployed.Â  Therefore, the
  family court did not err by imputing an income of $4,000 per month to
  Husband.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
II.  Marital Home
Husband
  avers the family court erred in valuing the martial home at $230,000.Â  We
  disagree. 
The
  family court has broad discretion in determining how marital property is to be
  valued and distributed; therefore, the court may use any reasonable means to
  divide the property equitably, and its judgment will be disturbed only where an
  abuse of discretion is found.Â  Wooten, 364 S.C. at 541-45, 615 S.E.2d at
  102-05.Â  In reviewing the family courtâ€™s equitable apportionment of marital
  property, an appellate courtâ€™s role is to examine the fairness of the
  apportionment as a whole.Â  Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 24, 553 S.E.2d 251, 255
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Generally, an appellate court will affirm the
  family court if it can be determined the judge addressed the factors under the
  marital property statute sufficiently for the appellate court to conclude the
  judge was cognizant of the statutory factors.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537
  (Ct. App. 2001); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (1985).Â  Further, the family court may accept the valuation of one
  party over another, and the courtâ€™s valuation of marital property will be affirmed
  if it is within the range of evidence presented.Â  Woodward v. Woodward,
  294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  
At trial, Wife and her father testified the house was worth about
  $230,000.Â  Also, Husband listed the house as being worth $230,000 on
  refinancing documents.Â  Husband did not present any evidence the house was
  worth more than $230,000; therefore, Husband, after making no effort in valuing
  the marital home, cannot now argue the family courtâ€™s determination is
  unsupported by the evidence.Â  See Hough v. Hough, 312 S.C. 344,
  347, 440 S.E.2d 387, 389 (Ct. App. 1994) (finding because Husband failed to
  offer values for certain household goods at trial, he could not appeal the
  family courtâ€™s valuation of those goods).Â  Furthermore, Husband bears the
  burden in demonstrating the family court committed reversible error.Â  See Honea v. Honea, 292 S.C. 456, 458, 357 S.E.2d 191, 192 (Ct. App. 1987) (explaining
  the burden is on appellant to show the family court committed reversible error,
  and a party cannot sit back at trial without offering proof, then come to the
  appellate court complaining of the insufficiency of evidence to support the
  family courtâ€™s findings).Â  However, Husband provides no evidence that conclusively
  demonstrates the family courtâ€™s findings are incorrect.Â  Even assuming the
  family court erred in its valuation of the marital home, Husband fails to
  establish the error was prejudicial to him. Â Cox v. Cox, 290 S.C. 245, 248,
  349 S.E.2d 92, 93 (Ct. App. 1986) (stating a party cannot complain of an error that
  his own conduct has induced).Â  Therefore, the family court did not err by
  determining the marital home was worth $230,000. Â Â Â 
III.  Equitable Division
Husband
  maintains the family court erred in distributing sixty percent of the marital
  property to Wife.Â  We disagree. 
â€œThe division of marital property is within the discretion of the
  family court judge and the judgeâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal
  absent an abuse of discretion.â€ Â Craig
    v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 290, 617 S.E.2d 359, 361 (2005). Â Section
  20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) provides
  fifteen factors for the family court to consider in apportioning marital
  property and affords the family court with the discretion to give weight to
  each of these factors â€œas it finds appropriate.â€Â  â€œOn appeal, this court looks
  to the overall fairness of the apportionment and it is irrelevant that this court might have weighed specific factors
  differently than the family court.â€ Â Greene v. Greene, 351
  S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Additionally, â€œ[w]hile there is certainly no recognized
  presumption in favor of a fifty-fifty division, we approve equal division as an
  appropriate starting point for a family court judge attempting to divide an
  estate of a long-term marriage.â€Â  Doe v. Doe, 370 S.C. 206, 214, 634
  S.E.2d 51, 56 (Ct. App. 2006); see Avery v.
    Avery, 370 S.C. 304, 311, 634 S.E.2d 668,
  672 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  However, â€œthis equal division of marital assets can . . .
  be altered in favor of one spouse depending on the circumstances of each
  case.â€Â  Doe v. Doe, 370 S.C. 206, 215, 634 S.E.2d 51, 56 (Ct. App. 2006).
In this case, even though Husband and Wife were married for ten
  years, the family court found, and we agree, Husbandâ€™s adultery caused the
  breakup of the marriage, and thus, is an appropriate consideration for
  equitable apportionment.Â  See id. (holding wifeâ€™s adultery caused
  the breakup of the marriage, and thus, was an appropriate consideration for
  equitable apportionment); Greene, 351 S.C.
  at 341, 569 S.E.2d at 400 (finding the facts and
  circumstances of the case, including Wifeâ€™s marital misconduct, rendered the
  equal division of marital assets fair and reasonable).Â  Husbandâ€™s adultery also
  caused him to abandon Norwalk, which adversely affected the partiesâ€™ economic
  circumstances and the value of their marital estate.Â  Additionally, in dividing
  the estate, the family court took into consideration that Wife has custody of
  the coupleâ€™s two children.Â  Therefore, the division was not inequitable and the
  family court did not err in awarding Wife sixty percent of the marital
  property.
IV.  Indemnity
Husband
  contends the family court lacked jurisdiction to order him to indemnify Wife
  against any judgment awarded in the lawsuit brought by Noble Enterprises.Â  We
  disagree. 
â€œFor
  purposes of equitable distribution, a â€˜marital debtâ€™ is a debt incurred for the
  joint benefit of the parties regardless of whether the parties are legally
  liable or whether one party is individually liable.â€Â  Wooten, 364 S.C.
  at 546, 615 S.E.2d at 105.Â  Section 20-7-472(13) of the South Carolina Code (Supp.
  2007) creates a rebuttable presumption that a debt of either spouse incurred
  prior to the beginning of marital litigation is a marital debt and must be
  factored in the totality of equitable apportionment.Â  Hickum v. Hickum,
  320 S.C. 97, 102, 463 S.E.2d 321, 324 (Ct. App. 1995). Â â€œThe burden of proving
  a debt is nonmarital rests upon the party who makes such an assertion.â€ Â Id. at 103, 463 S.E.2d at 324.Â  
Here,
  the record clearly indicates Wifeâ€™s liability to the corporation arose during
  the marriage because Norwalk was formed as a family business.Â  Accordingly, the
  family court had jurisdiction to identify and apportion this martial debt under
  its general powers to equitably divide a marital estate.Â  Nevertheless, Husband
  maintains the family court erred in awarding indemnification because Wife
  failed to request such relief in her pleadings.Â  However, this issue is not
  preserved for review because Husband failed to raise it in his Rule 59(e),
  SCRCP, motion.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406,
  412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be
  raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled
  upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  Therefore,
  the family court did not err by ordering Husband to indemnify Wife against any
  judgment awarded against her.Â  
V.  Attorneysâ€™ Fees
Husband
  asserts the family court erred in awarding Wife attorneysâ€™ fees in the amount
  of $12,800.Â  We disagree. 
The family court is authorized by statute to award attorneyâ€™s fees
  in conjunction with marital litigation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(2) (Supp. 2007).Â  When determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the
  following factors should be considered: (1) the partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her
  own attorneyâ€™s fee; (2) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and (3)
  effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  Glasscock
    v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161 n.1, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 n.1 (1991).Â  If
  the court determines attorneyâ€™s fees are warranted, the court should consider six
  factors when determining the amount to award: (1) the nature, extent, and
  difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) counselâ€™s professional standing; (4) the contingency
  of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6) the customary
  legal fees for similar services.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe decision to award
  attorneyâ€™s fees is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial judge and
  the award will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Marquez
    v. Caudill, 376 S.C. 229, 246, 656 S.E.2d 737, 745 (2008).
In this case, the family
  court found Wife â€œhas no ability to pay her attorneyâ€™s fees while the Husband,
  having represented himself and with a very substantial earning potential, can
  afford to pay attorneyâ€™s fees.â€Â  Further, the family court thoroughly analyzed
  each of the factors outlined above and detailed its findings in its final
  order.Â  The courtâ€™s findings are further supported by the affidavits of Wifeâ€™s
  counsel submitted to the family court and contained in the record.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of
  discretion in the family courtâ€™s award of attorneysâ€™ fees to Wife.
CONCLUSION
Therefore,
  the family courtâ€™s order is hereby
AFFIRMED.
SHORT
  and KONDUROS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J. concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Larontae
      Scroggins, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â R. Knox McMahon, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-428
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed July 23,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of
  Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Special Assistant Attorney General, Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Larontae
  Scroggins appeals his convictions for armed robbery and possession of a firearm
  during the commission of a violent crime.Â  On appeal, Scroggins argues the trial
  court erred in allowing the State to introduce evidence from an out-of-court
  statement made by a non-testifying witness on redirect examination where the statement
  was prejudicial hearsay.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
At trial, the State called Yuri McLamore, Detective Eric Russell,
  and Officer Donall Stoudemire to testify. Â Renee Mullinax, the individual
  allegedly kidnapped by Scroggins, was not called as a witness at trial.Â  During
  cross-examination of Detective Russell, Scrogginsâ€™ counsel questioned Detective
  Russell about statements Mullinax made to police regarding events following the
  robbery, which were recorded in Detective Russellâ€™s report of the case.Â 
  Specifically, Scrogginsâ€™ counsel asked Detective Russell about Mullinaxâ€™s
  statements whereby she admitted to having consensual sex with Scroggins
  following the alleged robbery.Â  Following this line of questioning, the State
  raised the issue of whether Scrogginsâ€™ counsel had, by questioning Detective
  Russell about Mullinaxâ€™s statement, opened the door to inquiry of other
  statements made by Mullinax to Detective Russell about the events of the
  robbery.Â  The trial court ruled that Scrogginsâ€™ counsel had opened the door. 
Accordingly, during the redirect examination of Detective Russell,
  the State inquired about statements Mullinax made about the robbery.Â  When
  asked specifically what Mullinax had to say about the robbery, Scrogginsâ€™
  counsel objected arguing the line of questioning was based on hearsay.Â  The
  trial court overruled the objection and Detective Russell proceeded with his
  testimony. 
Scroggins asserts the trial court erred in allowing the State to
  introduce hearsay testimony of Mullinaxâ€™s statement to Detective Russell
  regarding the robbery.Â  Scroggins further asserts the statements were
  prejudicial because they confirmed McLamoreâ€™s testimony regarding the events
  surrounding the robbery, and, in particular, the presence of the gun.Â  We find
  the circuit court did not commit reversible error.Â  See State v. McFarlane, 279 S.C. 327, 330, 306 S.E.2d 611, 613 (1983) (â€œIt is well settled
  that the admission of improper evidence is harmless where it is merely
  cumulative to other evidence.â€); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507,
  435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) (any error in admission of evidence cumulative to
  other unobjected-to evidence is harmless).Â  
Even if the door had not
  been opened and the trial court erred in allowing the admission of the
  testimony at issue, we find the error to be harmless. Â Since McLamore testified
  earlier in the trial that Scroggins had robbed him at gunpoint and took
  Mullinax at gunpoint against her will, the disputed testimony by Detective
  Russell is merely cumulative.Â  Moreover, Detective Russell testified, without
  objection, that Mullinaxâ€™s account of the events confirmed what McLamore had
  stated.Â  This testimony by Detective Russell was placed into evidence before
  the disputed testimony at issue herein.Â  Since McLamore testified first,
  followed by Detective Russellâ€™s testimony without objection that Mullinax
  confirmed what McLamore stated, the subsequent admission by the court of other
  statements by Mullinax through Detective Russell was therefore harmless even if
  the admission was in error.Â  
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS, THOMAS,
  and PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Jonathan Dennis
      Carter, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lancaster County
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-429
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed July 24,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, South Carolina Commission
  on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the
  Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Douglas A. Barfield, Jr., of
  Chester, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Jonathan
  Dennis Carter appeals his conviction of second-degree burglary.Â  He contends
  the trial court erred in failing to charge the jury on third-degree burglary
  because he disputed prior burglary convictions in his name and those prior
  convictions were an element of second-degree burglary.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On November 22, 2004, police responded to
  a report of a cracked window at the First Washington Baptist Church (the
  Church) in Lancaster, South Carolina, while the Church was closed.Â  The police
  discovered two broken windows and some blood around one of the windows and in other
  parts of the Church.Â  A vacuum cleaner, a crock pot, a microwave oven,
  communion glasses, chemical spray, and hot dogs were missing from the Church.Â  Shortly after their arrival, the police recovered some of the items from a
  wooded area behind the Church.
That same morning, Carter was
  spotted carrying a bag and walking from a pawn shop near the Church into the
  woods.Â  The police later brought Carter into the police station, where
  he waived his rights and admitted throwing a cinder block through the church
  window.Â  He further confessed to stealing the missing items from the
  church and eating the hotdogs.
A grand
  jury indicted Carter for second-degree burglary and petit larceny.Â  At trial, the
  State called the Lancaster Clerk of Court (the Clerk) to testify to demonstrate
  Carter had previously been convicted of two or more burglaries.Â  However,
  Carter argued the Clerkâ€™s records did not sufficiently prove Carter had two
  prior burglary convictions.Â  The trial court agreed the Clerkâ€™s testimony was insufficient
  and an assistant solicitor and a sheriffâ€™s deputy both involved in the cases of
  the prior burglaries testified in camera Carter was the person they
  dealt with in the prior burglaries.Â  The trial court determined the State had
  presented sufficient evidence to create an issue for the jury.Â  Carter
  requested the jury be charged with third-degree burglary in addition to
  second-degree burglary because there was reasonable doubt Carter had committed
  the previous burglaries.Â  The trial court stated, â€œIâ€™ll think about it, but Iâ€™m
  probably not going to charge that.â€
At
  trial, the Clerk testified the Clerkâ€™s office had sentencing sheets indicating
  Carter pled guilty to burglaries in 2002 and 2004.Â  The sentencing sheets all
  listed the defendant as Jonathan Dennis Carter and they contained the same
  birth date and social security number.Â  However, the Clerk testified the
  Clerkâ€™s office did not complete the forms and stated he could not testify as to
  the accuracy of the information about Carter on the forms.Â  Thereafter, Deputy
  Brent Williams testified he had served the warrant on Carter for the 2002 burglary
  and transported him to the detention center.Â  He identified Carter as the
  person he arrested but did not know if Carter was convicted of the charge.
Additionally,
  Deputy James Shaw testified he arrested Jonathan Dennis Carter at the scene of
  a burglary in 2004.Â  He identified Carter as the person he had arrested but did
  not recall seeing Carter plead guilty to the burglary.Â  Subsequently, probation
  agent Tim Williams testified he processed Carter for probation the same day he
  was sentenced for the 2004 burglary but was not present in the courtroom when
  the guilty plea was rendered.
At the
  close of the Stateâ€™s case, Carter argued the Stateâ€™s evidence was insufficient
  to identify Carter as the person convicted of the prior crimes.Â  Carter did not
  indicate what relief he sought other than he was not seeking a directed verdict.Â 
  The trial court denied the motion.Â  During closing arguments, Carter argued the
  State failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt he had committed two prior
  burglaries because the Stateâ€™s evidence of arrest did not prove he was
  convicted of the prior burglaries.Â  He further argued no witness testified the
  information on the sentencing sheets was correct or the signatures on them were
  his.
The trial court charged the jury on
  second-degree burglary but not third-degree burglary.Â  However, the trial court
  did instruct the jury the State must prove beyond a reasonable doubt Carter had
  two or more prior convictions of burglary.Â  The jury convicted Carter of both
  second-degree burglary and petit larceny.Â  The trial court sentenced him
  to life without parole for the burglary because of his two prior convictions
  for serious offenses.Â  Additionally, the trial court sentenced him to ten years
  imprisonment for the petit larceny, to run concurrently.Â  The trial court also
  pronounced Carter guilty but mentally ill by stipulation of the parties.Â  This
  appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases,
  the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€Â  State v. Baccus,
  367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  Thus, an appellate court is
  bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Carter
  argues the trial court erred in refusing to charge the lesser included offense
  of third-degree burglary.Â  We disagree.
The
  trial court is required to charge the law as determined from the evidence
  presented at trial.Â  See State v. Gates, 269 S.C. 557, 561, 238 S.E.2d 680, 681 (1977).Â  If any evidence supports a charge, it should be given.Â  State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999).Â  â€œThe
  trial court commits reversible error if it fails to give a requested charge on
  an issue raised by the evidence.â€Â  Id.Â  However,
  a trial courtâ€™s refusal to give a requested charge must be both erroneous and
  prejudicial to warrant reversal.Â  State
    v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 261, 565 S.E.2d 298, 303 (2002).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[f]ailure
  to give requested jury instructions is not prejudicial
  error where the instructions given afford the proper test for determining the
  issues.â€Â  Id. at 263, 565 S.E.2d at 304.Â  
A
  person is guilty of second degree burglary â€œif the person enters a building
  without consent and with intent to commit a crime therein, and . . . [t]he burglary is
  committed by a person with a prior record of two or more convictions for
  burglary.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-312(B)(2)
  (2003).Â  â€œA person is guilty of burglary in the third degree if the person
  enters a building without consent and with intent to commit a crime therein.â€Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-313(A) (2003).
The existence
  of evidence to sustain a lesser offense determines whether the charge should be
  submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Funchess, 267 S.C. 427, 430, 229 S.E.2d
  331, 332 (1976).Â  The mere contention the jury might accept the Stateâ€™s
  evidence in part and reject it in part will not suffice.Â  Id. (quoting State v. Hicks, 84
  S.E.2d 545, 547 (N.C. 1954)).Â  In State
    v. Fields, 356 S.C. 517, 523,
  589 S.E.2d 792, 795 (Ct. App. 2003), the defendant was charged with first
  degree criminal sexual conduct but argued even though he
  did not testify or present any evidence on his own behalf, the jury could have
  disbelieved a portion of the Stateâ€™s evidence and determined the sex was
  consensual, and thereby found him guilty of the lesser offense of assault and
  battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN).Â  However, this court held the
  defendantâ€™s â€œmere assertion that the jury might have disbelieved the Stateâ€™s
  evidence that the sex was not consensual and on the remaining evidence found
  him guilty of ABHAN does not entitle him to have the lesser
    offense submitted to the jury.â€Â  Id. at 523-24, 589 S.E.2d at 795.Â  See also State
      v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 22, 518 S.E.2d 278, 285 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding the possibility the jury might have disbelieved the
  Stateâ€™s evidence as to the circumstances of aggravation and on the remaining
  evidence found the defendant guilty of simple assault and
  battery did not entitle the defendant to have the lesser offense submitted to
  the jury when no evidence tended to show defendant was guilty only of simple
  assault and battery).
At
  trial, Carter relied on a Second Circuit Court of Appeals case that held,
  â€œWithout more, a court record showing a conviction of a similarly named person
  (especially an eighteen-year-old record) cannot conceivably furnish assurance
  beyond a reasonable doubt that it pertains to the present defendant.â€Â  United
    States v. Jackson, 368 F.3d 59, 62 (2nd Cir. 2004).Â  The court further
  rejected â€œthe governmentâ€™s proposed rule that sufficiency is satisfied as the
  result of the defendantâ€™s failure to offer proof in rebuttal.â€Â  Id.Â  
However,
  in the present case, the trial court relied on more than just an outdated court
  record: (1) the Clerkâ€™s records indicated someone named Jonathan Dennis Carter,
  with the same birth date and social security number, pled guilty to burglary in
  2002 and 2004, much more recent than the eighteen-year-old record in Jackson;
  (2) the arresting officers testified they arrested Carter for burglary in 2002
  and 2004; and (3) a probation agent testified he processed Carter on the same
  day as the 2004 guilty plea.Â  Carter has only argued the jury might reject the
  Stateâ€™s evidence in part, which is not sufficient to warrant a jury charge.Â  See Funchess, 267 S.C. at 430, 229 S.E.2d at 332.Â  Accordingly, the trial
  court did not err in failing to charge the jury with third-degree burglary.

    CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., KONDUROS, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
