THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Case no.
          2001-CP-40-3330/Newsmall Clemson, LLC, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Earth
          Management Systems, Inc., Respondent,
        Case no.
          2002-CP-40-2778/John H. Newsome, Jr., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Earth
          Management Systems, Inc., 
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-430
  Heard December 12, 2007 â€“ Filed July 31,
2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED AND REMANDED IN
PART


  
    
      
        T. Alexander Beard, of Mount Pleasant, for Appellants.
        Charles E. Hill, James L. Werner, and Michael E. Kozlarek, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Newsmall
  Clemson, LLC, and its sole member, John H. Newsome, Jr., (collectively
  Newsmall) appeal the trial courtâ€™s grantingÂ  of directed verdict to Earth
  Management Systems, Inc. (Earth Management), on its causes of action for
  negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and violation of the South Carolina
  Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA).Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.Â  
FACTS
Newsmall was interested in purchasing
  forty-three acres of undeveloped commercial property (the Property) in Columbia, South Carolina at the Clemson Road exit of Interstate 20 for commercial
  development.Â  Charles Small and his company, Diversified Development, represented
  Newsmall and were responsible for developing Newsmallâ€™s projects.Â  Small was
  Newsomeâ€™s business partner in several ventures, and he and his company were
  experienced in real estate development.Â  
Small hired Earth Management, on behalf of Newsmall, to perform a
  Phase I Environmental Site Assessment (Phase I Assessment) of the Property.Â  The
  American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) standard for Phase I
  Assessment Process provides the purpose of a Phase I Assessment is to define
  good commercial and customary practice for conducting an environmental site
  assessment of commercial real estate.Â  The intent is to enable a user to
  qualify for the innocent landowner defense to Comprehensive Environmental
  Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA)[1] liability.Â  The ASTM standard provides
  the goal of the Phase I Assessment is to identify recognized environmental
  conditions.Â  It defines recognized environmental conditions as â€œthe
  presence or likely presence of any hazardous substances or petroleum products
  on a property under conditions that indicate an existing release, a past
  release, or a material threat of a release of any hazardous substances or
  petroleum products into structures on the property or into the ground,
  groundwater, or surface water of the property.â€Â  (emphasis omitted).Â  The
  standard defines hazardous substance as â€œa substance defined as a hazardous
  substance pursuant to CERCLA.â€Â  
The ASTM standard describes the components
  included in a Phase I Assessment as: Â (1) records review; (2) site
  reconnaissance; (3) interviews with current owners and occupants and government
  officials; and (4) report.Â  The
  list of standard environmental sources includes state landfill and/or solid
  waste disposal site lists.Â  The standard provides:

  One or more additional state sources or local sources of
    environmental records may be checked, in the discretion of the environmental
    professional, to enhance and supplement federal and state sources . . . .
    Factors to consider in determining which local or additional state records, if
    any, should be checked include (1) whether they are reasonably ascertainable,
    (2) whether they are sufficiently useful, accurate, and complete in light of
    the objective of the records review . . . , and (3) whether they are generally
    obtained, pursuant to local good commercial or customary practice, in initial
    environmental site assessments in the type of commercial real estate
    transaction involved. 

Further, the
  standard provides a list of local sources that may be useful including â€œDepartment
  of Heath/Environmental Division.â€Â  
The ASTM standard also provides â€œ[a]ll
  obvious uses of the property shall be identified from the present, back to the
  propertyâ€™s obvious first developed use, or back to 1940, whichever is earlier.â€Â  Additionally, it provides a list of standard historical sources. Â Those
  sources include aerial photographs, property tax files, and recorded land title
  records.Â  However, the standard cautions if recorded land title records are
  used, they cannot be the sole historic source consulted.Â  
On January 28, 1999, Earth Management issued a report following
  its investigation.Â  The report contained an executive summary, which
  provided: â€œ[e]vidence of debris dumping was observed, but nothing of a
  hazardous nature was identified, no extensive dumping was observed, and no
  evidence of debris burial in old borrow pits was identified.â€Â  The executive
  summary further stated: 

  During the 1980s, the eastern half . . . contained several borrow
    areas from which sand was excavated by a local contractor.Â  This practice ceased
    in the mid 1980s, with the excavations backfilled with on-site sand.Â  There is
    no evidence to suggest that foreign materials were introduced into the borrow
    pits and buried.

The executive
  summary concluded: Â â€œNo further investigation for environmental considerations is
  recommended at this time.â€Â  
Newsmall purchased the Property on April
  29, 1999.Â  In the process of constructing a road, contractors unearthed a
  landfill.Â  Newsmall found an agreement between Loveless & Loveless
  and Interstate Investment Associates, a former owner of the Property, that
  provided for the mining of sand and also for the implementation and management
  of a refuse dump on the property.Â  The agreement was recorded in the Richland
  County Deeds Book.Â  Additionally, the South Carolina Department of Health and
  Environmental Control (DHEC) had a file detailing the history of the mining and
  landfill operations and identified the Property as a former asphalt plant.Â  
Newsmall excavated part of the landfill to build the road. Â The debris
  could not be reburied because it contained several types of debris such as
  metal, tires, plastic bags, household trash, and construction debris, and DHEC
  regulations required the different types of debris be separated before
  disposal. Â Shortly thereafter, Newsmall hired Geo-Systems to
  determine the amount and location of the former landfill.Â  Geo-Systems
  discovered construction debris, household garbage, paint cans, oil cans,
  batteries, tires, and medical waste.Â  Newsmall paid for the cleanup
  where the road was placed, but did not remove the remaining debris.Â  
Newsmall commenced an action against Earth
  Management, asserting in amended complaints[2] negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and violation of the South Carolina
  Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA), Sections 39-5-10 to -560 of the South
  Carolina Code (1985 & Supp. 2007).Â  At the close of Newsmallâ€™s case, Earth
  Management moved for a directed verdict on all of Newsmallâ€™s causes of action,
  and the trial court granted the motion.Â  Newsmall filed a Rule 59,
  SCRCP, motion, which the trial court denied.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
When ruling on a directed verdict motion, the trial court is required
  to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom
  in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party. Â Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  â€œIf more than one
  reasonable inference can be drawn or if the inferences to be drawn from the
  evidence are in doubt, the case should be submitted to the jury.â€Â  Chaney v. Burgess, 246 S.C. 261, 266, 143 S.E.2d 521, 523 (1965).Â  â€œWhen considering directed verdict motions,
  neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide
  credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.â€Â  Erickson
    v. Jones St. Publishers, L.L.C., 368 S.C. 444, 463, 629 S.E.2d 653, 663 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Timeliness
Earth Management
  asserts Newsmall did not file its appeal in a timely manner.Â  Specifically,
  Earth Management argues because Newsmall did not make a motion for a new trial
  at the conclusion of the case and instead, without the permission of the trial
  court, filed the motion within ten days, the motion was not properly before the
  trial court. Therefore, Earth Management maintains Newsmall had thirty days
  from the conclusion of the case instead of thirty days from the trial courtâ€™s
  ruling on the motion in which to file its appeal.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[A] party must
  make a motion for a new trial promptly after the jury is discharged or request
  ten days within which to make the motion.â€Â  Boone v. Goodwin, 314 S.C.
  374, 376, 444 S.E.2d 524, 525 (1994).Â  Although the trial court has discretion
  to sua sponte grant a new trial within ten days following the close of a
  case, that power cannot remedy a partyâ€™s filing a motion for a new trial
  without the courtâ€™s permission at the close of the case.Â  See id. 
Although Newsmallâ€™s motion was titled â€œmotion for a
  new trial,â€ the subject of the motion was both a request for a new trial and
  for the trial court to reconsider its decisions.Â  The motion cites to
  Rule 59, SCRCP, but does not specify whether it is referring to sections 59(a)
  through 59(d), which refer to motions for a new trial, or section 59(e), which
  refers to a motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  The supreme court held it
  was proper to treat a plaintiffâ€™s written motion as a Rule 59(e) motion even
  though it was erroneously captioned as a motion for new trial.Â  Fields v.
    Reg. Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 27, 609 S.E.2d 506, 510 (2005).Â 
  The courts must treat a motion based on its substance and effect as opposed to
  how it was captioned by a party.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, we view the motion
  as both one for a new trial and one to alter or amend the judgment.Â  
Unlike
  a motion for a new trial, a motion to alter or amend does not require the
  courtâ€™s permission to file the motion.Â  However, both motions stay the time to
  file an appeal, and the thirty day time period does not begin to run until the
  appellant receives the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the motion.Â  Rule 59(f), SCRCP.Â 
  Because Newsmallâ€™s motion was at least in part a motion to alter or amend, the
  motion stayed the time for filing an appeal.Â  Newsmall filed its motion within
  thirty days of the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the motion, and thus, the appeal was
  timely.Â  Accordingly, Newsmallâ€™s appeal is properly before this court.
II. Directed Verdict on Negligence
  Claim
Newsmall contends the trial court erred in granting
  Earth Management a directed verdict on its negligence claim.Â  Specifically,
  Newsmall maintains the evidence presented at trial showed Earth Management
  breached its duty to Newsmall.Â  Further, Newsmall argues the evidence presented
  showed Newsmall suffered damages as a result of the breach of duty.Â  We agree.
To
  establish a negligence cause of action, the plaintiff
  must prove: Â (1) a duty of care owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) breach of
  that duty by a negligent act or omission; and (3) damage proximately resulting
  from the breach of duty.Â  J.T. Baggerly v. CSX Transp., Inc., 370 S.C. 362, 368-69, 635 S.E.2d 97, 101 (2006).Â  â€œProximate cause requires proof of: (1) causation-in-fact, and (2)
  legal cause.â€Â  Id. at 369, 635 S.E.2d at
  101.
Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â 
  Breach of Duty
Mark Sellers, an environmental consultant testifying on behalf of
  Newsmall, stated he believed the report did not meet the standard of care for
  the requirements of a Phase I Assessment.Â  He further testified:

  There
    are a number of deviations from the standards which either may or may not have
    been part of the scope of work.Â  The biggest problem I have is that the report
    presents information that there has been at least surface landfilling and that
    there were pits that had been filled and that aerial photographs are referenced
    for those activities, yet it draws the conclusion that no additional work needs
    to be done, and I donâ€™t think the evidence in the report would indicate that no
    additional work needs to be done.Â  

Additionally,
  Robert White, an expert in ASTM standards, testified he did not believe Earth
  Management had met its standard of care in performing the Phase I Assessment.Â  He testified Earth Management â€œfailed to identify recognized environmental
  conditions on the property, that being the landfill.Â  I believe they failed to
  readily review available records with DHEC.â€Â  Moreover, White testified, â€œI
  donâ€™t know that they even did a search of recorded land titles.Â  And then . . .
  they obviously didnâ€™t identify the existence of the landfill on the property.â€Â 
  He also testified based on Earth Managementâ€™s findings, it should have
  recommended a Phase II Assessment of the Property.Â  Finally, he
  testified in his opinion, the landfill was a recognized environmental condition.Â  
When considering the directed verdict motion, the trial court
  asked â€œwhere is anything on this site right now under expert testimony or lay
  testimony here today or during this week that says thereâ€™s a likelihood of
  anything hazardous out there other than Mr. White?â€Â  Newsmall replied, â€œYour
  honor, then thatâ€™s for them to argue, his credibility, and â€“ â€ The trial court
  responded, â€œThatâ€™s for right now, because Iâ€™ll deal with Mr. White in a minute,
  but other than Mr. White identify some testimony.â€Â  Later, the trial court
  stated â€œnobody even came in here today with the exception of Mr. White, I will
  give you that Mr. Beard [Newsmallâ€™s counsel] and said that anything falls in
  the purview of CERCLA, which is what the Phase I was intended to look at to
  begin with.â€Â  The trial court did not mention White again.Â  
The
  testimony of Sellers and White supports Newsmallâ€™s claim that Earth Management
  breached its duty.Â  The trial court even acknowledged Whiteâ€™s testimony
  indicated the duty was breached.Â  In deciding the directed verdict motion, the
  trial court improperly weighed the evidence.Â  However, the trial courtâ€™s duty
  is not to weigh the evidence or determine matters of credibility.Â  Rather, those
  matters are left to the jury. Â See Erickson v. Jones St. Publishers, L.L.C., 368 S.C. 444, 463, 629 S.E.2d
  653, 663 (2006) (holding the trial court does not have authority to decide
  credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence when
  considering a directed verdict motion).Â  Therefore, some evidence presented at
  trial suggested Earth Management breached its duty to Newsmall. 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  B.Â 
  Damages
Because
  we determine Earth Management breached its duty, we now turn to whether
  Newsmall provided any evidence of damages.
Small testified he
  did not believe Newsmall could sell the Property that had not been cleaned up
  because no buyer would know what they were buying.Â  Small further testified the
  real estate community advised Newsmall not to even attempt to sell the Property
  where the landfill was located.Â  The engineer who worked for the construction
  company that discovered the debris, Ben Whetstone, estimated the total cleanup
  costs to be $1,636,575.Â  Sellers testified he found that estimate to be
  reasonable.Â  
In addition, Newsmall had sold two lots on the Property before discovering
  the landfill.Â  After discovering the landfill and learning those two
  lots included the former landfill, Newsmall had to purchase additional property
  to offer as an exchange to the purchasers.Â  One party received 2 acres
  instead of the original 1.37 acres.Â  The other party received 3.6 acres with a
  slope easement as well as frontage on Percival Road, instead of the original
  3.5 acre tract with no frontage.Â  Additionally, Newsmall
  discounted the price by $100,000 for another parcel that contained debris.Â  
Newsmall
  presented evidence of the cost of clearing the debris, the impact on the
  ability to sell the property, and the expenses they incurred having to appease
  purchasers of lots contaminated by the landfill.Â  A jury could reasonably find
  Newsmall would not have suffered these damages if Earth Management had
  discovered the problems with the Property and Newsmall had purchased other
  property instead.Â  
Accordingly,
  because the record contained evidence Earth Management breached its duty and
  Newsmall, as a result, suffered some damages, the trial court erred in granting
  Earth Managementâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the issue of negligence.
III. Directed Verdict on
  Negligent Misrepresentation
Newsmall
  asserts the trial court erred in granting Earth Managementâ€™s motion for a
  directed verdict on negligent misrepresentation.Â  We agree.
To establish a claim for negligent misrepresentation, Newsmall
  must be able to prove the following elements: Â â€œ(1) the defendant made a false representation to the
  plaintiff; (2) the defendant had a pecuniary interest in making the statement;
  (3) the defendant owed a duty of care to see that he communicated truthful
  information to the plaintiff; (4) the defendant breached that duty by failing
  to exercise due care; (5) the plaintiff justifiably relied on the representation;
  and (6) the plaintiff suffered a pecuniary loss as the proximate result of his
  reliance upon the representation.â€Â  AMA Mgmt. Corp. v. Strasburger, 309
  S.C. 213, 222, 420 S.E.2d 868, 874 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œA duty to exercise
  reasonable care in giving information exists when the defendant has a pecuniary
  interest in the transaction.â€Â  Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C.
  459, 474, 581 S.E.2d 496, 504 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  It is not necessary for
  Newsmall to prove Earth Management knowingly made a false representation.Â 
  Unlike fraud, which requires the conveyance of a known falsity, negligent
  misrepresentation is predicated upon transmission of a negligently made false
  statement.Â  Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 43, 557 S.E.2d 676, 681 (Ct. App.
  2001).Â  
Earth Management
  asserts the purported misrepresentation relied on by Newsmall, that â€œno further
  investigation for environmental considerations is recommended at this timeâ€ was
  not a representation of a then existing fact but rather was an opinion.Â  This
  court held in a fraud action that the false representation must be one of fact
  rather than the mere expression of an opinion.Â  Winburn v. Ins. Co. of N.
    America, 287 S.C. 435, 440, 339 S.E.2d 142, 145 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding
  statement that a person was a â€œgood mechanicâ€ did not support a claim for
  fraud).Â  However, we find that even if the recommendation was merely an
  opinion, the Phase I Assessment does contain factual representations that could
  support a claim for negligent misrepresentation.Â  
In the
  Phase I Assessment, Earth Management stated â€œ[N]o evidence of debris burial in
  old borrow pits was identified.â€Â  There is evidence in the record to support
  Newsmallâ€™s contention that Earth Management was negligent in failing to review
  the historical sources that indicated the Property had been used as a garbage
  dump.Â  Thus, the jury could find Earth Management negligently misrepresented
  there was no evidence of debris burial on the Property.Â  
In
  addition, Earth Management stated that former owner Thomas McTeer had been
  interviewed and related that no foreign material was ever placed in the pits
  and buried.Â  However, McTeer testified that when Earth Managementâ€™s Senior
  Hydrogeologist, Brad Hubbard, interviewed him, he told Hubbard that he did not
  know what was in the borrow pits, that Loveless and Loveless had the lease
  agreement on it and he could contact them.Â  It is for the jury to decide
  whether Earth Management made a misrepresentation regarding the interview with
  McTeer.Â  
Furthermore,
  Earth Management stated the Property was only zoned C-3, general commercial
  while in fact portions of the Property were zoned M-1, light industrial.Â  Thus,
  the record contains evidence of alleged factual misrepresentations that could
  support Newsmallâ€™s claim.Â  
Earth
  Management argues Newsmall did not reasonably rely on any of the purported
  misrepresentations.Â  â€œWhether reliance is justified in a given situation
  requires an evaluation of the circumstances involved, including the positions
  and relations of the parties.â€ Â Redwend, 354 S.C. at 474, 581 S.E.2d at
  504. Â First, Earth Management asserts no one with Newsmall read the detailed
  Phase I Assessement.Â  However, Newsmallâ€™s developer, Small, testified that he
  looked through the entire assessment.Â  When asked if he studied it, he stated,
  â€œCould I pass an exam on it?Â  I donâ€™t think so.Â  But I probably could tell you
  what was in it, yes.â€Â  In a deposition, Small admitted that he did not recall
  the disclosures of debris dumping in the assessment.Â  In addition, on cross-examination,
  he admitted he had not read every word of the assessment.Â  Although there is a
  conflict in Smallâ€™s testimony, it is for the jury to decide whether he read the
  report and justifiably relied on the representations made in it.Â  
Earth Management
  also asserts the disclosures it made in the Phase I Assessment should have
  alerted Newsmall to the possibility of the existence of debris.Â  The report
  does note the existence of scattered debris on the Property shown on a 1981 aerial
  photograph raised a potential concern that the â€œpossible use of the site as a
  borrow pit may have resulted in debris burial . . . .â€Â  However, the report
  maintains in several places that â€œno evidence of debris burial in old borrow
  pits was identified.â€Â  
The
  ASTM Standards call for the environmental profession to review historical
  sources such as land title records and state landfill and/or solid waste
  disposal site lists and to interview local government officials. Â The list of local sources that may be
  useful includes â€œDepartment of Health/Environmental Division.â€Â  Although Newsmall may have discovered the landfill
  if it had made its own records search, a jury may reasonably find Newsmall had
  a right to rely on the professional it hired to make such a review.Â  The
  issue of whether Newsmall reasonably relied upon the representations Earth
  Management made in the report is one for the jury to decide.Â  See Unlimited
    Servs., Inc. v. Macklen Enters., Inc., 303 S.C. 384, 387, 401 S.E.2d 153,
  155 (1991) (â€œThe general rule is that questions concerning reliance and its
  reasonableness are factual questions for the jury.â€).
Taking
  the evidence in the light most favorable to Newsmall, we find Newsmall
  presented sufficient evidence to allow the court to submit the issue of
  negligent misrepresentation to the jury.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial
  court erred in granting Earth Management directed a verdict on the claim for
  negligent misrepresentation.Â  
IV. Directed Verdict on UTPA
Newsmall
  contends the trial court erred in granting Earth Managementâ€™s motion for a
  directed verdict on violation of the UTPA.Â  We disagree.
The
  UTPA creates a private right of action in favor of â€œ[a]ny person who suffers
  any ascertainable loss of money or property, real or personal, as a result of
  the use or employment by another person of an unfair or deceptive method, act
  or practice declared unlawful by Â§ 39-5-20 . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-140(a)
  (1985).Â  In order to recover pursuant to the UTPA a plaintiff must demonstrate:
  Â (1) a violation of the Act by the commission of an unfair or deceptive act in
  trade or commerce; (2) proximate cause; and (3) damages.Â  Schnellmann v. Roettger, 368 S.C. 17, 23, 627 S.E.2d 742, 745-46 (Ct. App. 2006) affâ€™d
    as modified, 373 S.C. 379, 645 S.E.2d 239 (2007). Â â€œAn act is â€˜unfairâ€™ when it is offensive to public policy or when
  it is immoral, unethical, or oppressive.â€Â  Bessinger v. BI-LO, Inc., 366 S.C. 426, 432, 622 S.E.2d 564, 567 (Ct. App. 2005). 
A
  plaintiff bringing a private cause of action under the UTPA is required to
  allege and prove the defendantâ€™s actions adversely affected the public
  interest.Â  Daisy
    Outdoor Adver. Co. v. Abbott, 322 S.C. 489, 493, 473 S.E.2d 47, 49 (1996).Â  â€œ[U]nfair or deceptive acts or practices in the conduct of trade
  or commerce have an impact upon the public interest if the
  acts or practices have the potential for repetition.â€ Â Noack Enters., Inc. v. Country Corner Interiors of
    Hilton Head Island, Inc., 290 S.C. 475, 480, 351 S.E.2d 347, 350-51 (Ct. App.
  1986).Â  Plaintiffs in prior cases often
  have shown potential for repetition in two ways: Â (1) by showing the same kind
  of actions occurred in the past, thus making it likely the actions will
  continue to occur absent deterrence; or (2) by showing the companyâ€™s procedures
  create a potential for repetition of the unfair and deceptive acts.Â  Daisy, 322 S.C. at 496, 473 S.E.2d
  at 51.Â  
Newsmall
  asserts Earth Management violated the UTPA by (1) failing to provide Newsmall
  with a proposal as required under the ASTM Standards or (2) failing to explain
  or otherwise inform Newsmall of (i) any restrictions or narrow scope
  limitations based on technical engineering standards incorporated only by
  reference in the final Phase I Report and (ii) that the alleged limitation on
  the Report varied from customs and practices in the industry or Newsmallâ€™s
  reasonable expectations.Â  Â Â Â Â  
We
  agree with the trial court that Newsmall has failed to show a violation of the
  UTPA.Â  Newsmall failed to provide evidence that the same kind of actions
  occurred in the past.Â  Newsmall asserts the trial court is to blame for this
  failure as it attempted to introduce into evidence an unrelated proposal by
  Earth Management, but the trial court refused to admit the proposal.Â  Although
  Newsmall argues the trial court erred in this decision, it provides no
  reasoning or law to support this argument.Â  Accordingly, we find the issue of
  the admissibility of the proposal is not properly before this court.Â  Mulherin-Howell
    v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 600, 608 S.E.2d 587, 593-94 (Ct. App. 2005) (noting
  when an appellant fails to cite any supporting authority for his position and
  makes conclusory arguments, the appellant abandons the issue on appeal).Â  The
  proposal was the only evidence Newsmall cites to show actual repetition.Â  Â 
In
  addition, Newsmall failed to provide evidence that Earth Managementâ€™s
  procedures create a potential for repetition of the unfair and deceptive acts.Â 
  Newsmallâ€™s claim for a UTPA violation is based on an alleged dispute between it
  and Earth Management as to the scope of the Phase I Assessment.Â  The
  Limitations section of the Phase I Assessment clearly provides the report â€œwas
  performed in accordance to performance standards outlined in ASTM Standard
  1527(97)â€.Â  Newsmall claims it did not know the standard and argues the scope
  was intended to be broader for this project.Â  However, it provided no evidence
  other clients of Earth Managment would have a similar dispute over the scope of
  the project.Â  Newsmall relies on a statement Earth Managementâ€™s expert witness,
  Thomas Donn, made in his deposition, although the trial court denied Newsmallâ€™s
  attempt to introduce excerpts of the deposition into evidence.Â  In the
  deposition, Donn testified that the tank, soft sand, the depression, the borrow
  pits, and the partially buried construction debris were not â€œrecognized
  environmental conditions.â€Â  However, when asked if they were environmental
  concerns, he answered, â€œYeah, I would say to some degree, and thatâ€™s why I
  would show those and indicate those in the report.Â  There wouldnâ€™t be any reason
  to include the report if it didnâ€™t have any environmental significance.â€ These
  environmental concerns were in fact noted in the Phase I Assessment.Â  Even if
  we considered Donnâ€™s deposition, we fail to see how it supports Newsmallâ€™s
  claim for a UTPA violation.Â  
We
  find no evidence in the record that this was any more than a dispute of the
  scope of the Assessment limited only to the parties involved.Â  See Jefferies v. Phillips, 316 S.C. 523, 527, 451 S.E.2d 21, 23 (Ct. App. 1994) (stating
  conduct that only affects the parties to the transaction provides no basis for
  a UTPA claim).Â  Accordingly, the
  trial court did not err in granting Earth Managementâ€™s motion for a directed
  verdict on the UTPA violation.Â  
Â V.Â  Deposition
Newsmall maintains
  the trial court erred in finding it did not have discretion to consider
  allowing an excerpt from Thomas Donnâ€™s deposition because Newsmall failed to
  provide timely notice.Â  We find no prejudice in this ruling.Â  See Lucas
    v. Sara Lee Corp., 307 S.C. 495, 498, 415 S.E.2d 837, 839 (Ct. App. 1992)
  (stating appellant must show error and prejudice in the exclusion of
  evidence).Â  As stated above, even when considering the excerpts from Donnâ€™s
  deposition, we find the trial court correctly granted a directed verdict on Newsmallâ€™s
  UTPA claim.Â  In addition, Newsmall will be able to provide timely notice if it
  wishes to offer the excerpts at the retrial of the negligence and negligent
  misrepresentation claims.Â  
VI. Affirmative Defenses
Newsmall argues the trial court erred in considering
  Earth Managmentâ€™s affirmative defenses when ruling on the directed verdicts.Â  Earth
  Management conceded this issue at oral argument.Â  Accordingly, to the extent
  the trial court ruled on the affirmative defenses, this ruling is reversed.Â  
CONCLUSION
We
  hold the trial court erred in directing verdicts in favor of Earth Management
  on Newsmallâ€™s claims for negligence and negligent misrepresentation.Â  We also
  hold the trial court correctly granted a directed verdict on Newsmallâ€™s claim
  for violation of the UTPA.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED
  IN PART; REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART.
HUFF
  and PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY, AJ., concur.


[1] 42 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 9601 - 9675 (West 2005 & Supp.
  2008).Â  
[2] John H. Newsome, Jr. and Newsmall Clemson, LLC filed
  separate actions against Earth Management.Â  The actions were consolidated for
  trial and appeal.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Silver Bay
          Seafood Restaurants, Inc., Respondent,
        v.
        Lynn D. Mann, Appellant.
        Lynn D. Mann, Third Party
          Plaintiff,
        v.
        Koustantivos
          Sialmas, Panagiotis Sialmas, Vassilios Sialmas, and Larry Velaetis, Third Party
          Defendants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-431
Heard May 8, 2008 â€“ Filed July 31, 2008Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        R. Lawton McIntosh, of Anderson, for Appellant.
        Stephen P. Groves, Sr., of Charleston, Thomas L. Stephenson, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lynn
  Mann appeals the Master-In-Equityâ€™s failure to find Silver Bay Seafood
  Restaurants, Inc. (Silver Bay) breached a commercial lease by failing to pay
  rent.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In December 2001, Silver Bay leased commercial property owned by Mann.Â  The Lease was to commence on April 1, 2002 and
  end on March 31, 2007. Â Article V of the Lease provided the Lessee would â€œpay
  the rental when due.â€
Article III of the Lease, entitled Repair
  and Maintenance, provided: 

  Subject to the Lesseeâ€™s right to inspect the premises prior to
    entering into this Lease, as additional consideration for the rental paid
    hereunder, the Lessee agrees to accept the Premises in the same condition and
    state of repair as exists upon the date of taking possession hereunder and
    thereafter, the Lessee shall be responsible for all maintenance and upkeep
    thereon.Â  Lessee agrees to promptly report any and all repair and maintenance
    problems to the Lessor.

Additionally,
  under Article IV of the Lease, the Lessor was to â€œ[t]imely pay all taxes which
  may become due and owing on the Premises so long as not to interfere with
  possession thereof by the Lessee.â€Â  The Lease also required the Lessor

  to make additions totaling 1500 square feet, 1000 square feet in
    the form of a party room and 500 square feet in the form of a lighthouse in
    accordance with those certain plans and specifications (and any additions or
    alterations thereto) attached as Exhibit A.Â  Lessor also agrees to make
    improvements to the roof and parking lot of the said Premises in accordance
    with Lesseeâ€™s direction.

An addendum to
  the Lease provided a partial list of improvements Silver Bay agreed to make,
  including improvements to the bathroom, kitchen, electricity, and plumbing, as
  well as making â€œoutside walls the same all around.â€
Both Silver Bay and Mann renovated the
  portions of the Property as the Lease required.Â  Silver Bayâ€™s personnel visited
  the Property daily and Mann was also there regularly.Â  On April 1, 2002,
  Silver Bay took possession of the Property and began operating a restaurant.
On June 1, 2004, a Notice of Levy was posted on the Property.Â  Mann
  paid the taxes owed the next day.Â  However, Mann did not remove the notice until
  the following week, immediately after Silver Bay informed him of its presence.Â  On June 9, 2004, Silver Bayâ€™s attorney sent Mann a letter regarding the
  Notice of Levy and â€œcertain repairs promised to be repaired on the property.â€Â  On June 30, 2004, Silver Bayâ€™s attorney sent another letter to Mann
  asserting Silver Bay had lost $30,000 as a result of the Notice of Levy.Â  Â The
  letter also mentions a â€œwall problemâ€ and states the Lease is null and void and
  Silver Bay intended to vacate the Property on July 31, 2004.Â  On July 21,
  2004, Silver Bay informed Mann it would not vacate the Property but instead
  would continue to make its monthly rental payments and sue Mann for damages.Â Â  
On August 18, 2004, Silver Bay commenced an action against Mann
  for breach of contract for Mannâ€™s faulty construction of an addition required
  by the Lease and failure to pay taxes.Â  Mann answered, counterclaimed,
  and filed a third-party complaint against the guarantors of the Lease, seeking
  rents due and other damages under the Lease.Â Â  
In December 2004, Silver Bay subleased the Property to Neptune Diner.Â  Silver Bay continued making the monthly
  rental payments until Neptune Diner vacated the Property in September 2005.Â  Subsequently,
  Mann listed the Property for lease with a real estate agent.
On April 13, 2006, the parties consented to refer the matter to a
  master.Â Â  At trial, one of the guarantors, Larry Velaetis, testified the
  roof leaked the first rain after Silver Bay opened the restaurant.Â  Â He
  further testified the leaks continued following every rain.Â  Metz Looper, a
  former magistrate, testified that the three times he visited Silver Bay, he observed a musty odor, water on the floor, and the roof leaking.
Velaetis testified Silver Bay orally informed Mann after the first
  leak occurred and once the leaks continued but never provided written notice or
  demand regarding the leaks, despite the fact the Lease required any notice or
  demand be in writing.Â  Velaetis admitted Silver Bay did not keep any
  record of the dates of the leaks.Â  He also acknowledged Silver Bay failed to inspect the roof when it took possession and once the roof began leaking,
  it did not have it inspected to determine the cause of the leaks.Â  Mann
  testified that at Silver Bayâ€™s request, he had sent a roofer to the Property
  after Silver Bay took possession.Â  Additionally, Mann testified he had a duty
  to provide a properly constructed roof.Â  
The master denied both Silver Bayâ€™s and Mannâ€™s requests for
  damages.Â Â  Regarding Silver Bayâ€™s damages, the master found:

  Silver[ B]ay did nothing to document the occasions when water
    allegedly leaked into the restaurant.Â  Although the Court finds credible
    testimony to establish some water damage due to leaks, there was no evidence
    presented establishing a link between these events and Silver[ B]ayâ€™s declining
    revenues, the number of occasions the leaks supposedly occurred or the extent
    of damages allegedly incurred as a result of the leaks. 

The master determined
  Silver Bay â€œfailed to establish its business was damaged due to water
  intrusion . . . [and] lost revenues with reasonable certainty.â€Â  The
  master further found â€œ[t]he alleged damages due to the posting of delinquent
  tax notice, if at all, are inconsequential.Â  The notice was posted for a rather
  short period of time and the taxes were paid by Mann in short order.â€ Â 
As to Mannâ€™s damages, the master determined: 

  As stated, the Court finds there was credible testimony of some
    water damage due to leaks.Â  However, I find there is a significant question of
    breach of the lease by Mann based upon his failure to properly repair the
    roof.Â  Accordingly, the Court denies Mannâ€™s claim for damages due under the
    Lease.Â  

Mann filed a Rule
  59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration that the master denied.Â  This
  appeal followed.
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
â€œAn
  action seeking damages for breach of contract is . . . an action at law . . . .â€Â  Kuznik v. Bees Ferry Assocs., 342 S.C. 579, 589, 538 S.E.2d 15,
  20 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In an appeal from the final judgment of a master, this
  court has the same scope of review as if the appeal is from the circuit court
  without a jury.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237,
  391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1990). Â On appeal of an action at law tried without a
  jury, this courtâ€™s review is limited to correction of errors at law.Â  Epworth
    Childrenâ€™s Home v. Beasley, 365 S.C. 157, 164, 616 S.E.2d 710,
  714 (2005).Â  The masterâ€™s findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in
  a law action.Â  King v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 317 S.C. 385, 388-89, 453
  S.E.2d 885, 888 (1995).Â  

  We may not consider the case based on our view of the
    preponderance of the evidence, but must construe the evidence presented to the
    Master so as to support his decision wherever reasonably possible. Â We must look at the evidence in the light most
    favorable to the respondents and eliminate from consideration all evidence to
    the contrary.

Sheek v. Crimestoppers
  Alarm Sys., 297 S.C. 375, 377,
  377 S.E.2d 132, 133 (Ct. App. 1989) (citations omitted).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mann argues the master
  erred in failing to award damages to him under the Lease.Â  Specifically, Mann
  asserts Silver Bay did not establish the elements for constructive eviction
  because it did not vacate the Property before filing its cause of action.Â  We
  disagree.
A
  tenant asserting constructive eviction must show: (1) some intentional act or
  omission of the landlord deprived the tenant of possession or substantially
  interfered with the tenantâ€™s beneficial use or enjoyment of the leased premises
  and (2) as a result of the act or omission by the landlord, the tenant abandoned
  the premises.Â  Pleasantburg Warehouse Co. v. Global Distribution, Inc.,
  287 S.C. 422, 423, 339 S.E.2d 135, 136 (Ct. App. 1985). 

  There
    is no â€œconstructive evictionâ€ if the tenant continues in possession of the
    premises however much he may be disturbed in the beneficial enjoyment.Â  To establish a constructive
    eviction of the premises, in order to avoid liability for rent, the tenant must
    surrender or abandon the
    premises within a reasonable
  time after the landlordâ€™s wrongful act.

 49 Am. Jur. 2d Landlord & Tenant Â§ 598 (2006) (footnotes omitted).
Mann contends
  Silver Bay does not meet the elements for constructive eviction because it was
  still in possession of the Property when it brought the breach of contract
  action. Although Silver Bay retained possession of the Property after filing
  suit, it continued to pay rent until Neptune Diner vacated the Property.Â 
  Further, the masterâ€™s order contains no indication he relied on the theory of
  constructive eviction in finding Silver Bay was not liable for damages to
  Mann.Â  Rather, the order seems to indicate the master found Silver Bay was not
  liable because Mann had breached the terms of the Lease by failing to properly
  repair the roof.Â  When â€œa contract is not performed, the
  party who is guilty of the first breach is generally the one upon whom all
  liability for the nonperformance rests.â€ Â Silver v. Aabstract Pools & Spas, Inc., 376 S.C.
  585, 594, 658 S.E.2d 539, 543 (Ct. App. 2008) (quoting Willms Trucking Co. v. JW Constr. Co., 314
  S.C. 170, 178, 442 S.E.2d 197, 201 (Ct. App. 1994)).Â  
The master found â€œcredible testimony of
  some water damage due to leaksâ€ as well as a â€œsignificant question of breach of
  the lease by Mann based upon his failure to properly repair the roof.â€Â  The
  record contains evidence to support finding Mann breached the Lease by failing
  to repair the roof.Â  Mann conceded he had a duty to provide a properly
  constructed roof.Â  Velaetis testified the roof leaked from the first rain after
  Silver Bay took possession.Â  Additionally, Looper testified he observed the
  leaks.Â  Questions regarding credibility
  and weight of evidence are exclusively for the master.Â  Sheek v.
    Crimestoppers Alarm Sys., 297 S.C. 375, 377, 377 S.E.2d 132,
  133 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  Accordingly,
  because the record contains evidence indicating Mann breached the contract
  first by failing to properly repair the roof, the master did not err in failing
  to award Mann damages.
Based
  on the foregoing, the order of the master is
AFFIRMED.

HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.
